page.title: 2011 attack on the Israeli Embassy in Egypt

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = 2011 attack on the Israeli embassy in Egypt | partof = [[Aftermath of the 2011 Egyptian revolution|events surrounding the 2011 Egyptian revolution]] | image =
[[File:Egypt location map.svg|300px]]
[[File:Red pog.svg|7px]]
'''The attack site'''
| caption = | place = Israeli embassy at [[Giza]], [[Egypt]]{{cite news|last=Fahmy|first=Mohamed Fadel|title=Egypt declares state of alert in wake of attack on Israeli Embassy|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/09/09/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=hp_t1on|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011|work=CNN}} | coordinates = {{coord|30|01|43.20|N|31|13|01|E|display=inline}} | date = 9–10 September 2011 | status = | goals = | howmany1 = Several thousand protesters | causes = | methods = [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]], rioting, [[online activism]], infiltration{{cite news|last=Kessler|first=Oren|title=Egypt vows to prosecute those who targeted embassy|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=237437|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=10 September 2011}} | injuries = ~1,049 Egyptian protesters | fatalities = 3 Egyptian protesters | arrests = | concessions = }} On 9 September 2011, several thousand protesters forcibly entered the Israeli embassy in [[Giza]], [[Greater Cairo]], after breaking down a recently constructed wall built to protect the compound.{{cite news|title=The return of calm in front of the embassy of Israel in Giza|url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-671532|work=CNN iReport|accessdate=30 April 2012}}{{cite news|last=Alabass|first=Bassem|title=Israeli workers in Egypt fly home in fear for safety|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/3/12/21049/Business/Economy/Israeli-workers-in-Egypt-fly-home-in-fear-for-own-.aspx|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=12 September 2011}} The protesters later broke into a police station and stole weapons, resulting in police using [[tear gas]] in an attempt to protect themselves. The demonstrators eventually broke through the security wall and entered the offices of the embassy. Six members of the embassy staff, who had been in a "[[safe room]]", were evacuated from the site by Egyptian [[commando]]s, following the personal intervention of United States President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite news|last=Hadid|first=Diaa|title=Egypt commandos save 6 Israelis in embassy attack|url=https://news.yahoo.com/egypt-commandos-save-6-israelis-embassy-attack-190607978.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011}}{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Dan|title=Israel lauds Obama's role in Cairo crisis|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFL5E7KA0UV20110910|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011|work=Reuters}}{{cite news|title=Obama asks Egypt to protect Israeli embassy|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/obama-asks-egypt-protect-israeli-embassy|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011}} Following the attack, the Israeli deputy ambassador remained in Cairo; 85 staff members and their families returned to Israel.{{cite news|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David|title=After Attack on Embassy, Egypt Vows a Tougher Stance on Protests|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/11/world/middleeast/11egypt.html?_r=1|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=10 September 2011}} The Egyptian army declared a state of alert. == Background == {{main|Egypt–Israel relations}} [[File:Burning the Israeli flag at embassy in Cairo.jpg|thumb|right|On 15 May 2011, Egyptian protesters waved [[Palestinian flag]]s in front of the Israeli embassy in [[Giza]] as they burned a makeshift [[Israeli flag]].]] During 2011, relations between Israel and Egypt deteriorated after the resignation of Egyptian President [[Hosni Mubarak]], reaching their lowest point since peace was established between the nations by the [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty|1979 Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty]]. The Israeli-Egyptian border became a region of conflict and instability due to increased militant activity in Egypt's [[Sinai Peninsula]], and anti-Israeli sentiment was expressed in protests by masses of Egyptians in the streets of Giza. On 18 August 2011, a squad of militants crossed the border from the Sinai Peninsula into southern Israel, [[2011 southern Israel cross-border attacks|killing eight Israelis]]. The ensuing Israeli counter-terrorist operations in close proximity to the border resulted in the deaths of "at least three" Egyptian soldiers.{{cite news|title=Egypt says Israel apology of troop deaths is insufficient|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-08-21/world/israel.egypt.tensions_1_israel-and-egypt-egyptian-border-amos-gilad?_s=PM:WORLD|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=CNN|date=21 August 2011}} The soldiers' deaths by Israeli fire{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} ignited protests at the Israeli Embassy in Giza. During a demonstration on 20 August 2011, an Egyptian protester climbed 20-feet up the building's facade to remove the [[Israeli flag]]. The Egyptian [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] considered recalling the Egyptian ambassador in Tel Aviv. Eventually, Israel publicly apologized for the deaths of the Egyptian soldiers.{{cite news|title=Ehud Barak, Israel Defense Minister, Regrets Deaths Of Egyptian Troops|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/20/ehud-barak-egyptian-soldiers_n_932097.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=20 August 2011}}{{cite news|title=Israel Apologizes For Deaths Of Egyptian Troops In Shootout With Militants|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/08/20/israel-apologizes-for-deaths-egyptian-troops-in-shootout-with-militants/|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=20 August 2011|work=Fox News}} Egypt stated that Israel's apology was "insufficient."{{cite news|title=Egypt deems Israel's apology for policemen deaths 'insufficient'|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/egypt-deems-israel-s-apology-for-policemen-deaths-insufficient-1.379797|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=Haaretz Daily Newspaper|date=21 August 2011}} == The attack == {{see also|Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces#September}} On 9 September 2011, hundreds of Egyptian protesters began gathering outside of the Israeli embassy. Around 6:30 p.m. local time, they began to assault a concrete security perimeter wall with hammers and a [[battering ram]]. Egyptian authorities had erected the wall following intense protests in August. === Building infiltration === At 12:30 a.m. Saturday morning, several thousand protesters breached the security wall.{{cite news|title=Egyptians protest against military rule|url=http://aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/09/20119993150747146.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=9 September 2011}} By 1:00 a.m. they had entered the lobby and proceeded through the rest of the building. The demonstrators ransacked the embassy, located on the 20th and 21st floors of the building, and threw items including documents, some marked "[[confidential]]", from the windows of the building to the crowded street below.{{cite news|last=Ali|first=Mostafa|title=The storming of Cairo's Israeli embassy: an eyewitness account (part I)|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentP/1/20856/Egypt/The-storming-of-Cairos-Israeli-embassy-an-eyewitne.aspx|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011}} The documents were quickly scanned and publicly commented on.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} Israel later revealed that the remaining Israeli security staff had been separated from the rioters only by the steel door of a safe room in which they had taken refuge. In Jerusalem, Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and various other senior Israeli officials watched the events unfold from a direct feed from the surveillance cameras installed in the embassy. Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman Yigal Palmor estimated that about 3,000 protesters were involved in destroying the security wall. An Israeli diplomat condemned the attack as a "serious violation" of diplomatic behavior.{{cite news|title=Israel pulls envoy after embassy attack|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/09/201191064219436657.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011}} Immediately after the protesters had infiltrated the embassy, United States Secretary of Defense [[Leon Panetta]] received a call from Israeli [[Ministry of Defense (Israel)|Minister of Defense]] [[Ehud Barak]] asking for help. The United States assisted in assuring the protection of the Israeli embassy personnel.{{cite news|last=Ravid|first=Barak|title=U.S. told Egypt it must rescue Israeli embassy workers or suffer 'consequences,'|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/u-s-told-egypt-it-must-rescue-israeli-embassy-workers-or-suffer-consequences-sources-say-1.383675|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=Haaretz Daily Newspaper|date=10 September 2011}} Prime Minister Netanyahu later emphasized that he "would like to thank the US President Barack Obama for his help" in securing the lives of the Israeli embassy staff. === Rescue of embassy staff and end of the riots=== Six Israeli security staff who were on the premises hid inside a reinforced safe room. Egyptian commando forces entered the embassy building and rescued the six Israeli guards. All other embassy staff and their family members were escorted to [[Cairo International Airport]]. At 2:40 a.m., the Israeli ambassador and approximately 85 other Israeli diplomats and their family members arrived at the airport and were flown out of Egypt. Only the deputy Israeli ambassador remained in Egypt, staying at the United States embassy. A senior Egyptian security official stated that the Egyptian commandos had been sent to the embassy after Israeli Ambassador [[Itzhak Levanon]] spoke on the phone with an anonymous member of [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Egypt's ruling military council]], and asked him to arrange the safe evacuation of the embassy staff. The demonstration and ransacking of the embassy building continued into the early morning hours as the protesters burned tires and set several police cars on fire. The Egyptian police eventually suppressed the riots and dispersed the thousands of rioters by using tear gas and firing warning shots into the air. Prime Minister Netanyahu and former [[Mossad]] director [[Efraim Halevy]] praised the actions of American president Obama in helping with the evacuation.{{cite news|last=Wexler|first=Robert|title=Defending Obama’s pro-Israel credentials|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Op-EdContributors/Article.aspx?id=238954|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=22 September 2011}} == Aftermath == Following the attack on the embassy, the Egyptian army heightened the state of alert in the country and reinstated martial law, otherwise known as [[State of Emergency]], on a temporary basis.{{cite web|title=Egypt Declares Emergency After Attack on Israeli Embassy|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-09-10/egypt-declares-state-of-emergency-after-israeli-embassy-struck.html|publisher=Businessweek|accessdate=30 April 2012}} On the morning of Saturday, 10 September, Egypt's ruling military council rejected resignation requests that had been submitted by Egyptian Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]] and several Egyptian ministers. Their request was made because of the failure to handle the disturbances.{{cite news|last=Lina|first=Yang|title=Egypt's ruling military council rejects PM's resignation|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-09/10/c_131132013.htm|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011}} One day after the attacks on the embassy, a group of reporters were attacked by a crowd of people still lingering near the scene of the riots. A reporter and producer were knocked to the ground and trampled, but managed to get to a vehicle in which they retreated, with protesters throwing stones at them. They were able to flee the area without sustaining any major injuries.{{cite news|last=Watson|first=Ivan|title=Angry crowd turns on journalists reporting embassy attack in Egypt|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/09/10/egypt.journalists.targeted/|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=11 September 2011|work=CNN}} ===Arrests=== In August 2012, an Egyptian court convicted 76 Egyptians who were linked to the attack on the Israeli embassy. 75 of those convicted received suspended one-year sentences, and one Egyptian, Omar Afifi who had fled abroad,{{cite web | url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=282646 | title=Egypt orders man to jail over Israel embassy attack | publisher=The Jerusalem Post | work=Reuters; The Jerusalem Post | date=August 26, 2012 | accessdate=August 26, 2012}} who was tried in absentia was given a five-year prison term. Eight charges were listed by the court, including “an assault against diplomatic missions” and “sabotage.”{{cite web | url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/egypt-76-convicted-for-attack-on-israel-embassy/ | title=Egypt: 76 convicted for last year’s attack on Israeli Embassy | publisher=The Times of Israel | date=August 26, 2012 | accessdate=August 26, 2012}} == Official reactions == ;Involved parties * '''{{Flagu|Egypt}}:''' Following the attack on the Israeli Embassy in Giza, Information Minister [[Osama Heikal]] stated that Egypt is still committed to all of the international treaties to which it is a signatory, and added that Egypt is also committed to the safety of all foreign diplomats residing in the country. In addition, Heikal stated that measures would be taken to ensure no further disturbances would occur.{{cite news|title=Egypt: We are committed to maintaining Israel peace treaty|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/egypt-we-are-committed-to-maintaining-israel-peace-treaty-1.383642|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=Haaretz Daily Newspaper|date=10 September 2011}} * '''{{Flagu|Israel}}:''' During a televised press conference conducted on the evening of 10 September, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu emphasized the need to maintain Israel's strategic relations with Egypt, which is crucial to the region's stability. In addition, he thanked the Egyptian commando unit for preventing a disaster.{{cite news|title=Israel Embassy Attacked: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Condemns Violence In Egypt|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/10/israel-embassy-attacked-egypt_n_956627.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=10 September 2011}} Netanyahu also stated that the peace agreement with Egypt will be maintained in spite of the violent protests.{{cite news|title=Netanyahu: Peace agreement with Egypt will be maintained|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=237452|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=10 September 2011}} ; International * '''{{Flagu|Bahrain}}:''' Foreign Minister Sheik [[Khalid ibn Ahmad Al Khalifah]] condemned the attack on the Israeli Embassy in Giza. The minister said that "the failure to defend the embassy building is a blatant violation of the [[Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations|1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations]]."{{cite news|last=Nahmias|first=Roee|title=Egypt to try Israel embassy rioters|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4120247,00.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=10 September 2011}} * '''{{Flagu|Canada}}:''' Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] released a statement that said, "Our government strongly condemns the attack on the embassy of Israel in Egypt".{{cite web|title=AFP: Canada condemns attack on Israeli embassy in Egypt|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gON8NTBbMy_Bvm14RlCMBjaxRcAw?docId=CNG.4dd28a7c98f80c593e306e83d0eeefa5.8f1|accessdate=30 April 2012}} * '''{{Flagu|Germany}}:''' Foreign Minister [[Guido Westerwelle]] released a statement in which he condemned the attack on the Israeli embassy. In addition, the statement said that he expects "the Egyptian authorities to provide for the security of the embassy in accordance with international obligations. Any further escalation of the situation must be avoided."{{cite news|title=Germany condemns attack on Israeli Embassy in Cairo|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=237434|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=10 September 2011}} * '''{{Flagu|Iran}}:''' Deputy head of the [[Islamic Consultative Assembly|Majlis]] Committee on National Security and Foreign Policy [[Esmail Kowsari]] said that members of the Iranian parliament had expressed full support for the "ransacking" of the Israeli embassy in Cairo.{{cite news|title=Iran Majlis hails raid on Israel embassy|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/198690.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=[[Press TV]]|date=12 September 2011}} * '''{{Flagu|United Kingdom}}:''' Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] condemned the attacks on the Israeli embassy, stating that Egypt is responsible for protecting diplomatic property. "I strongly condemn the attack on the Israeli Embassy in Cairo. We have urged the Egyptian authorities to meet their responsibilities under the [[Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations|Vienna Convention]] to protect diplomatic property and personnel, including the Israeli Embassy in Cairo. They have reassured us that they take these very seriously."{{cite news|title=UK's Cameron condemns attack on Israeli Embassy in Cairo|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=237435|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=10 September 2011}} * '''{{Flagu|United States}}:''' In a statement to the press, the [[White House]] said that President Barack Obama expressed his great concern about the situation at the embassy and the security of the Israelis serving there.{{cite news|title=Israeli Embassy attacked in Egypt, envoy flees|url=http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=382788&catid=37|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Statesman|date=10 September 2011}} ==See also== {{Portal|Egypt|Israel}} *[[2011 attack on the British Embassy in Iran]] *[[2012 diplomatic missions attacks]] == References == {{reflist|35em|refs= {{cite news|title=Egyptians attack Israeli embassy; Obama is concerned|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=237393|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=10 September 2011}} }} == External links == * [http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=237423 Timeline of Israel embassy attack in Cairo] - published on the [[Jerusalem Post]] on 10 September 2011 * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14863671 In pictures: Cairo embassy attack] - published on [[BBC News]] on 10 September 2011 * [https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFL5E7KA10X20110910 Egypt vows to try those who targeted Israel mission] - published on [[Reuters]] on 10 September 2011 * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8754193/Israeli-ambassador-to-Egypt-flees-in-night-of-rioting.html Israeli ambassador to Egypt flees in night of rioting] - published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on September 10, 2011 * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14863756 Egyptian security forces clash with protesters] - published on [[BBC News]] on September 10, 2011 * [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/09/09/egypt.protests/ Egypt declares state of alert in wake of attack on Israeli Embassy] - published on [[CNN]] on September 10, 2011 * [http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/20875/Egypt/The-storming-of-Cairos-Israeli-embassy-eyewitness-.aspx The storming of Cairo's Israeli embassy: eyewitness account (part II)] - published on [[Ahram Online]] on September 11, 2011 {{2011 Egyptian revolution}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Embassy Attack, Israeli, 2011 In Cairo}} [[Category:2011 crimes in Egypt]] [[Category:2011 in international relations]] [[Category:Diplomatic incidents]] [[Category:Egypt–Israel relations]] [[Category:Political controversies]] [[Category:Attacks on diplomatic missions of Israel]] [[Category:Attacks on diplomatic missions in Egypt]] [[Category:Egyptian crisis (2011–14)]] [[Category:Giza]]

page.title: 2013 Kamduni gang rape and murder case

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=lots of POV, story telling, original content|date=August 2013}} {{essay-like|date=August 2013}} {{overly detailed|date=August 2013}} {{refimprove|date=August 2013}} }} {{Infobox news event | title = 2013 Kamduni Gang Rape and Murder Case | date = 7 June 2013 | time = 2:30 pm [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] ([[UTC+05:30]]) | place = Kamduni, North 24 Parganas, [[West Bengal]], [[India]] | accused = Ansar Ali
Saiful Ali
Aminoor Ali
Bhutto Molla
Enamul Molla
Amin Ali
Gopal Naskar
Bholanath Naskar | charges = | convictions = | verdict = | outcome = | reported injuries = | reported death(s) = 1 (female victim) }} On 7 June 2013, a 20-year-old college student was abducted, gang-raped and murdered in Kamduni village, 16 km from [[Barasat]], [[North 24 Parganas district]] about 20 km from main Kolkata. The victim, a second year BA student of Derozio College, was walking home along the Kamduni BDO Office Road in the afternoon, when she was abducted and taken inside a factory where she was gang-raped by eight muslim men. After raping her, the perpetrators tore apart her legs up to the navel, slit her throat and dumped her body into a nearby field.{{Cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/west-bengal-kamduni-victims-kin-want-death-for-rapists/1/582405.html|title=West Bengal: Kamduni victims kin want death for rapists|access-date=2016-07-20}} == Incident == At around 8:30 pm local time, the brothers of the victim discovered the brutalized, mutilated, naked body of their sister alongside a ''bheri'' in the At Bigha region of Kharibari in Rajarhat.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4272&boxid=22926640|title=তরুণীর দেহ উদ্ধার , সন্দেহ ধর্ষণ করে খুন|date=8 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} At around 9:45pm, an altercation and subsequent skirmish occurred between the villagers and the police when the latter tried to recover the body of the victim. The crowd damaged three police vehicles. At around 2 am, a huge police contingent recovered the victim's body from the villagers and sent it to Barasat for post mortem.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4322&boxid=22547468|title=প্রকাশনামেয়ে হারিয়ে ফুঁসছে বারাসত|date=9 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} On the evening of 15 June, a contingent of the Indian Reserve Battalion started flag march in Kamduni.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4493&boxid=3436218|title=কামদুনির প্রতিবাদ থামতেই কি গ্রামে হাজির আধা সেনা|last=Das|first=Atanu|date=17 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} In spite of the paramilitary vigil a team of Citizen's Forum visited Kamduni.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4496&boxid=31446125|title=কামদুনির প্রতিবাদ থামতেই কি গ্রামে হাজির আধা সেনা|last=Das|first=Atanu|date=17 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} Several women's organizations, including Matangini Mahila Samiti, Maitri, Manabi, Ahalya and Chetana, visited Kamduni. On 17 June, [[Mamata Banerjee]], the Chief Minister of [[West Bengal]], visited Kamduni. She promised that charge sheet would be produced against the arrested within 15 days of the incident and that her government would plead for the capital punishment of the culprits. However, nothing has been done so far because of the stronghold of the [[Trinamool Congress]] in the area.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4509&boxid=15223171|title=দোষীদের ফাঁসির আবেদনই জানাব , আশ্বাস মমতার|last=Sengupta|first=Manipushpak|date=18 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} == Victim == The name of the victim is Shipra Ghosh. While some of the media have published her real name, others have used pseudonyms like Aparajita. The victim belonged to a [[Bengali Hindu]] family of the Kamduni village under Kirtipur II Gram Panchayat in the Barasat II Block in North 24 Parganas district.{{cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/archive/1130609/9south3.html|title=মেয়ে নন, তিনি যেন ছিলেন বাড়ির অভিভাবক|date=9 June 2013|work=Anandabazar Patrika|language=Bengali|accessdate=16 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} She was second among three siblings in the family of two brothers and one sister. Her father works as a mason helper in the construction sites, earning around Rs 150 - 200 per day. Her mother sells muri and chhatu. == Arrests == The residents of Kamduni caught hold of Ansar Ali, the prime accused, and handed him over to the police. After interrogation, he confessed to have committed the crime along with four others. Five persons were named in the FIR. Based on that, the district police arrested three persons in the early hours of 8 June. == Prosecution == The case is being investigated by the CID, West Bengal. On 16 June, the CID officers took the eight accused to Kamduni to reconstruct the incident amid tight security by the police and Indian Reserve Battalion. For 45 minutes, the accused recounted how they had gang raped and then murdered the victim, throwing her body over the boundary wall afterwards. Even fifteen days after the incident, no charge sheet was filed. On 22 June, Ansar Ali was remanded in judicial custody for 14 days.{{cite news|url=http://eisamay.indiatimes.com/articleshow/20718830.cms|title=কামদুনি-কাণ্ডে চার্জশিট জমা পড়ল না ১৫ দিনে|date=22 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}}{{cite news|url=http://www.abpananda.newsbullet.in/state/34/37935|title=১৫ দিন পরেও চার্জশিট পেশ হল না|date=23 June 2013|work=ABP Ananda|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013}} The accused and State Govt. want the legal proceedings shifted from Barasat court.{{cite news|title=কামদুনি মামলায় অভিযুক্তদের সমর্থন করল রাজ্য|url=http://zeenews.india.com/bengali/zila/kamduni-case_14791.html|accessdate=21 July 2013|newspaper=24 Ghanta|date=20 July 2013}} == Protests == === Protests by Kamduni residents === From the early morning of 8 June, the Kamduni residents began their protest at the Kamduni bus stop, demanding exemplary punishment for the culprits. [[Jyotipriya Mallick]], the Minister for Food and Supplies met the villagers and promised job for the victim's elder brother, which was promptly rejected by the villagers. The protesters were also visited by Haji Nurul Islam, the M.P. from Bashirhat and Nirmal Ghosh, the President of North 24 Parganas District Trinamool Congress. When the former blamed the CPI(M) for this crime, his car was damaged by the protesters.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4322&boxid=2242915|title=নারীশিক্ষার এক শিখা নিভে গেল|date=9 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} From the night of 7 June till 9 June, the protests were mainly held at the Kamduni bus stop on Rajarhat Main Road, 2 km from the Kamduni village.{{cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/archive/1130612/12pgn1.html|title=বিচার চেয়ে জেলা সদরে পাড়ি দিল কামদুনি|date=12 June 2013|work=Anandabazar Patrika|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} On 10 June, the Kamduni residents protested in front of Barasat II BDO Office. On 11 June, the Kamduni residents staged a protest march in Barasat. From the Kachari Maidan they proceeded to Champadali, where they were joined by the protesters of the Sutia rape case. Many people from Barasat and Naihati participated in the protest march. When the procession reached Champadali, the activists of Hindu Samhati were protesting the rape and murder. The procession then moved towards the court, from where another procession of the lawyers had started. On 12 June, the brothers of the victim met the Chief Minister at the Writers Building. The Chief Minister offered a government job to the elder brother, offered to bear the cost of treatment of the victim's parents and the cost of education of the younger brother. But the victim's brothers refused the help and demanded capital punishment for the victims.{{cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/archive/1130613/13pgn1.html|title=সাহায্য নয় শাস্তি চাই, মমতাকে কামদুনি|date=13 June 2013|work=Anandabazar Patrika|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} On 4 July, people of Kamduni protested against CID's incomplete charge sheet. They demanded exemplary punishment for the criminals.{{cite news|title=সিআইডি-র কুশপুতুল পোড়াল কামদুনি|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/archive/1130705/5pgn3.html|accessdate=7 July 2013|newspaper=Anandabazar Patrika|date=5 July 2013}} === Citizen's protests === [[File:Rally against Kamduni Rape and Murder case.jpg|thumb|The rally of intellectuals in Kolkata, against at Kamduni violence]] On 10 June, human rights group APDR staged a dharna in front of the Chief Minister's secretariat office, but the latter refused to meet them.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Kolkata/Kolkata-wakes-up-to-Barasat-protests/Article1-1075327.aspx|title=Kolkata wakes up to Barasat protests|date=12 June 2013|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=16 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} On 11 June, Hindu Samhati staged a protest rally and road blockade in Champadali, [[Barasat]], disrupting the traffic on [[Jessore Road]]. The activists clashed with the police and damaged police vehicles. The activists of Youth Congress gheraoed the Barasat police station and submitted a memorandum to the police. They also blocked the K N C Road disrupting the traffic. The lawyers of Barasat Bar took out a procession in protest against the crime. The body declared that no lawyer in Barasat would stand for the accused. In the evening a hundreds of residents brought out a candle light procession in Baguiati, Kolkata. On 14 June, the [[Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh]] backed civil society body Sachetan Nagrik Manch organized a silent march from College Square to Shyambazar crossing demanding capital punishment for the culprits.{{cite news|url=http://www.tndpost.com/nation/politics-india/protests-rock-kolkata-web-after-mamata-s-village-visit-106348.html|title=Protests rock Kolkata, web after Mamata's village visit|date=19 June 2013|work=The New Delhi Post|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=New Delhi}} On 16 June, members of a Facebook community staged a protest march in Dakbanglow More, [[Barasat]]. The students of [[Visva-Bharati University]] too staged a protest march. On 18 June, around 400 government employees of the Writers' Building marched around the Writers' Building in protest against the Kamduni gang rape and murder.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4522&boxid=143038562|title=প্রতিবাদী মহাকরণ , মুখর হবে রাজপথ|date=19 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} Eminent intellectuals including Shankha Ghosh Nabaneeta Dev Sen, Mrinal Sen, Mahashweta Devi and Tarun Majumder gave a call for a protest march from College Square to the Metro Channel on 21 June. On 20 June, eminent intellectuals including filmmaker [[Aparna Sen]] held a protest meet at College Square. On 21 June, the intellectuals of [[Kolkata]] led by poet [[Shankha Ghosh]] and actor [[Soumitra Chatterjee]] among others, convened a protest march from College Street to the Metro Channel in protest against the growing crimes against women in the state and the Barasat gang rape and murder incident in particular. Thousands of men and women including eminent intellectuals and students participated in the march. They were joined by activists of human rights organizations, different Naxalite factions, Left Front, Congress and transgender organizations. The residents of Kamduni, Sutia and Gede too participated in the march.{{cite news|url=http://www.epaper.eisamay.com/Details.aspx?id=4574&boxid=323931|title=মহামিছিল বার্তা দিল মমতাকে|last1=Sarkar|first1=Koushik|last2=Sengupta|first2=Manipushpak|date=22 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|accessdate=23 June 2013|location=Kolkata}} == Controversies == On 22 June, the Primary Education Council show caused Pradip Mukhopadhyay, the Headmaster of the B. R. Ambedkar Primary School in Kamduni, for bringing out a procession with the students in protest of the rape and murder.{{cite news|title=প্রধানশিক্ষককে শো-কজ|date=23 June 2013|work=Ei Samay|language=Bengali|location=Kolkata}} ==See also== *[[2012 Delhi gang rape case]] *[[1990 Bantala rape case]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Rape in India}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kamduni gang rape and murder case}} [[Category:Gang rape]] [[Category:Murder in 2013]] [[Category:Murder in India]] [[Category:Rape in India]] [[Category:Violence against women in India]] [[Category:Sex crimes in India]] [[Category:Crime in West Bengal]] [[Category:2013 crimes in India]] [[Category:Crime in Kolkata]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:June 2013 events]]

{{pp-vandalism|expiry=12:00, 1 September 2019|small=yes}} {{Infobox cricket tournament | name = ICC Cricket World Cup
England & Wales - 2019 | image = [[File:ICC Cricket World Cup 2019 logo.svg|200px]] | caption = Official Logo for ICC Cricket World Cup 2019 | fromdate = 30 May | todate = 14 July | administrator = [[International Cricket Council]] | cricket format = [[One Day International]] | tournament format = [[Round-robin tournament|Round-robin]] and [[Single-elimination tournament|Knockout]] | host = {{flagicon|ENG}} [[England]]
{{flagicon|WAL}} [[Wales]] | champions = | count = | participants = 10 | matches = 48 | attendance = | most runs = | most wickets = |drs=Yes| previous_year = 2015 | previous_tournament = 2015 Cricket World Cup | next_year = 2023 | next_tournament = 2023 Cricket World Cup | imagesize = 280px }} The '''2019 Cricket World Cup''' (officially '''ICC Cricket World Cup 2019''') is the 12th edition of the [[Cricket World Cup]], scheduled to be hosted by [[England]] and [[Wales]],{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4956010.stm |title=England lands Cricket World Cup |accessdate=2006-04-30|work=BBC Sport |date=2006-04-30}}{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/245814.html |title=England awarded 2019 World Cup |accessdate=2006-04-30|work=espncricinfo}} from 30 May to 14 July 2019.{{cite web|url= http://www.icc-cricket.com/cricket-world-cup/news/2015/media-releases/84891/outcomes-from-icc-board-and-committee-meetings|title= OUTCOMES FROM ICC BOARD AND COMMITTEE MEETINGS|publisher= ICC|date= 29 January 2015|accessdate= 29 January 2015|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150202205353/http://www.icc-cricket.com/cricket-world-cup/news/2015/media-releases/84891/outcomes-from-icc-board-and-committee-meetings|archive-date= 2015-02-02|dead-url= yes|df= }} The hosting rights were awarded in April 2006, after England and Wales withdrew from the bidding to host the [[2015 ICC Cricket World Cup]], which was held in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. The first match will be played at [[The Oval]] while the final will be played at [[Lord's]]. It is the fifth time that the Cricket World Cup will be held in England and Wales, following the [[1975 Cricket World Cup|1975]], [[1979 Cricket World Cup|1979]], [[1983 Cricket World Cup|1983]] and [[1999 Cricket World Cup|1999]] World Cups. The format for the tournament will be a single group of ten teams, with each team playing the other nine teams, and the top four teams progressing to a knockout stage of semi-finals and a final. The ten team tournament has gained criticism due to the lack of Associate teams in the tournament. Given the increase of the Test playing nations from 10 to 12, with the admission of [[Ireland cricket team|Ireland]] and [[Afghanistan national cricket team|Afghanistan]] in June 2017, it will be the first World Cup to be contested without all of the Test playing nations being present,{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/icc-world-twenty20-2016/content/story/994995.html|title=ICC's Richardson wants more teams in World T20}} and after the elimination of all the Associate teams at the [[2018 Cricket World Cup Qualifier|qualifying tournament]], this will be also be the first World Cup to feature no Associate members. == Qualification == {{main|2018 Cricket World Cup Qualifier}} The 2019 World Cup will feature 10 teams, a decrease from previous World Cups in 2011 and 2015 which featured 14 teams.{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/33296828| title= Cricket World Cup 2019 to stay at only 10 teams|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 June 2015|accessdate= 26 June 2015}} The hosts, England, and the top seven other teams in the [[ICC ODI Championship|ICC One Day International rankings]] as of 30 September 2017 earned automatic qualification, with the remaining two spots being decided by the [[2018 Cricket World Cup Qualifier]].{{cite web|url=http://www.icc-cricket.com/news/2015/media-releases/84879/afghanistan-and-ireland-receive-opportunity-to-qualify-for-the-icc-cricket-world-cup-2019-with-full-members|title=Afghanistan and Ireland receive opportunity to qualify for the ICC Cricket World Cup 2019 with Full Members|work=icc-cricket.com|access-date=2015-07-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150129062811/http://www.icc-cricket.com/news/2015/media-releases/84879/afghanistan-and-ireland-receive-opportunity-to-qualify-for-the-icc-cricket-world-cup-2019-with-full-members|archive-date=2015-01-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} At the time of the announcement of the qualification structure, [[ICC members|ICC Associate and Affiliate members]], who were guaranteed four spots in the previous two World Cup tournaments, could be represented by at most two teams, and possibly none at all if they were beaten by the lowest ranked Full Members in the Qualifier. It also meant that at least two of the 10 Test playing nations at the time of the announcement would have to play in the qualifying tournament, and could possibly miss the World Cup finals entirely. Following recent success, Ireland and Afghanistan were promoted into the ICC ODI Championship and have also since been promoted to full members of the ICC, becoming the newest Test cricketing nations. However, they still needed to qualify for the World Cup via the current process. Afghanistan won the qualifying tournament defeating the West Indies in the final. Both teams qualified for the World Cup, while Zimbabwe despite hosting the qualifying tournament failed to reach the final and will miss the World Cup for the first time since 1983.{{Cite web |url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/live-cricket-score-zimbabwe-vs-uae-icc-world-cup-qualifiers-2018-super-six-harare/story-v0K4NDjN5pGSvu4Ccu539N.html |title= UAE stun Zim |accessdate=26 March 2018 |work=hindustantimes}} Recently appointed full member Ireland will also miss the World Cup for the first time since 2007 and for the first time ever no Associate nation will be participating in the World Cup.{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/mar/23/afghanistan-ireland-cricket-world-cup-qualifier |title= Ireland miss out on World Cup for the first time since 2003 |accessdate=26 March 2018 |work= The Guardian}} [[File:2019 Cricket World Cup participating nations.svg|360px|thumb|Highlighted are the countries to participate in the 2019 Cricket World Cup. {{legend|#003|Qualified as host}} {{legend|#00f|Qualified via the [[ICC ODI Championship]] ranking}} {{legend|#080|Qualified via the [[2018 Cricket World Cup Qualifier|2018 qualifier]]}} {{legend|#fc0|Participated in the qualifier but failed to qualify}}]] {| class="wikitable" width="850" ! width="30%" |Means of qualification ! width="27%" |Date ! width="20%" |Venue ! width="5%" |Berths ! width="18%" |Qualified{{Cite web |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/650164 |title=Cricket World Cup: The Final 10 |accessdate=23 March 2018 |work=International Cricket Council}} |- |Host nation |30 September 2006{{cite web|url=https://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4956010.stm|title=England lands Cricket World Cup|work=BBC Sport|date=30 April 2006|accessdate=2 April 2018}} | {{n/a}} | style="text-align:center;" |1 |{{cr|ENG}} |- |[[ICC ODI Championship]] |30 September 2017 | Various | style="text-align:center;" |7 |{{cr|AUS}}

{{cr|WIN}} |- !Total ! colspan="2" | !10 ! |} ==Venues== {{Location map+|England|AlternativeMap=England and Wales location map.svg|width=300|float=right|caption=Venues in England and Wales|places= {{Location map~|England |lat=52.455814|long=-1.902489|position=left|background=|label=[[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Birmingham]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=51.477174|long=-2.584097|position=right|background=|label=[[Bristol County Ground|Bristol]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=51.487334|long=-3.191416|position=left|background=|label=[[Sophia Gardens (cricket ground)|Cardiff]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=54.849512|long=-1.560952|position=left|background=|label=[[Riverside Ground|Chester-le-Street]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=53.817686|long=-1.582070|position=left|background=|label=[[Headingley Cricket Ground|Leeds]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=53.003280|long=-1.144573|position=left|background=|label=[[Trent Bridge|Nottingham]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=53.479251|long=-2.247926|position=left|background=|label=[[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Manchester]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=51.529420|long=-0.172822|position=left|background=|label=[[Lord's]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=51.483769|long=-0.114850|position=right|background=|label=[[The Oval]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=50.924000|long=-1.321900|position=right|background=|label=[[Rose Bowl (cricket ground)|Southampton]]}} {{Location map~|England|lat=51.018905|long=-3.100891|position=right|background=|label=[[County Ground, Taunton|Taunton]]}} }} The fixture list for the tournament was released on 26 April 2018 after the completion of an [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) meeting in Kolkata. [[London Stadium]] had been named as a possible venue in the planning stages,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/cricket/38228798 |title=London Stadium could stage 2019 Cricket World Cup matches |date=6 December 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/dec/05/olympic-stadium-2019-cricket-world-cup-games-ecb|title=ECB considering using Olympic Stadium to host 2019 Cricket World Cup games|first=Exclusive by Tim|last=Wigmore|date=5 December 2016|publisher=|accessdate=23 January 2017|via=The Guardian}} and in January 2017 the ICC completed an inspection of the ground, confirming that the pitch dimensions would be compliant with the requirements to host ODI matches.{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/story/1079160.html |title=London Olympic Stadium gets ICC approval |accessdate=23 January 2017 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} However, when the fixtures were announced, London Stadium was not included as a venue.{{cite news| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/cricket/43903877| title= 2019 World Cup: London Stadium not one of 11 tournament venues| work=[[BBC Sport]]| date=26 April 2018| accessdate=26 April 2018}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; margin:0 auto; clear:both" |- ! This means a total of 45 matches will be played, with each team playing a total of nine matches. The top four teams from the group will progress to the knockout stage. A similar format was previously used in the [[1992 Cricket World Cup]]. ===Points table=== {{2019 Cricket World Cup Points Table}} ===Fixtures=== The ICC released the fixture details on 26 April ==Knockout stage== The knockout stage will see two semi-finals, with the winners of each progressing to the final at [[Lord's]]. On 25 April 2018, it was reported that Old Trafford and Edgbaston would host the two semi-finals, with all of the knockout games having a reserve day.{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/23309263/old-trafford-host-india-pakistan-world-cup-clash|title=Old Trafford to host India-Pakistan World Cup 21–27 April | num_teams = 12 | venues = 2 | cities = 2 | prevseason = [[2018 IIHF World Championship Division II|2018]] | nextseason = [[2020 IIHF World Championship Division II|2020]] }} The '''2019 IIHF World Championship Division II''' will be an international ice hockey tournament run by the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]]. The Group A tournament will be held in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] from 9 to 15 April and the Group B tournament will be held in [[México City]], [[Mexico]] from 21 to 27 April 2019.{{Cite web|url=https://www.new-iihf.com/en/events/2018/wm/news/3208/kazakhstan%2c-japan-get-top-events|title=Kazakhstan, Japan get top events|date=18 May 2018|work=new-iihf.com}} ==Group A tournament== {{Infobox international hockey competition | tourney_name = IIHF World Championship Division II A | year = 2019 | country = Serbia | dates = 9–15 April | num_teams = 6 | venues = 1 | cities = 1 | games = | goals = | attendance = | scoring_leader = | points = | website = [https://www.iihf.com/en/events/2019/wmiia Website] }} ===Participants=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Expand French|Élections législatives algériennes de 2017|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox Election | election_name = Algerian legislative election, 2017 | country = Algeria | type = parliamentary | ongoing = no | previous_election = Algerian legislative election, 2012 | previous_year = 2012 | next_election = | next_year = 2022 | seats_for_election = All 462 seats to the [[People's National Assembly]]
232 seats are needed for a majority | election_date = {{Start date|2017|05|04|df=y}} | turnout = | image1 = [[File:جمال ولد عباس (cropped).png|x150px]] | leader1 ={{ill|Djamel Ould Abbes|ar|جمال ولد عباس|fr|Djamel Ould Abbes|tr|Cemil Ul Abbas}} | party1 = National Liberation Front (Algeria) | last_election1 = 208 seats, 17.35% | seats1 = 164 | seat_change1 = {{decrease}} 44 | popular_vote1 = | percentage1 = | swing1 = | image2 = [[File:Ahmed Ouyahia 2011-05-29.jpg|x150px]] | leader2 = [[Ahmed Ouyahia]] | party2 = National Rally for Democracy (Algeria) | last_election2 = 68 seats, 6.86% | seats2 = 100 | seat_change2 = {{increase}} 29 | popular_vote2 = | percentage2 = | swing2 = | image3 = [[File:No image.svg|x110px]] | leader3 = [[Abderrazak Makri]] | party3 = [[Movement of Society for Peace|MSP]] | color3 = 009900 | last_election3 = | seats3 = 33 | seat_change3 = – | popular_vote3 = | percentage3 = | swing3 = | title = Prime Minister | before_election = [[Abdelmalek Sellal]] | after_election = [[Abdelmadjid Tebboune]] | before_party = National Liberation Front (Algeria) | after_party = National Liberation Front (Algeria) }} {{Politics of Algeria}} '''Parliamentary elections''' were held in [[Algeria]] on 4 May 2017.[http://www.euronews.com/2017/02/02/algeria-to-hold-parliamentary-election-on-may-4 Algeria to hold parliamentary election on May 4] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206185535/http://www.euronews.com/2017/02/02/algeria-to-hold-parliamentary-election-on-may-4 |date=2017-02-06 }} Euronews, 2 February 2017 ==Electoral system== The 462 members of the [[People's National Assembly]] are elected by [[proportional representation]] from 48 multi-member constituencies based on the [[Provinces of Algeria|provinces]]. Seats are allocated using the [[largest remainder method]].[http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2003.htm Al-Majlis Al-Chaabi Al-Watani (National People's Assembly)] IPU ==Campaign== Candidates began campaigning on 9 April 2017.{{cite web|title=Muted start to election campaigning in Algeria|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/04/muted-start-election-campaigning-algeria-170409134054847.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=9 April 2017}} ===Participating parties=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! colspan="2" | Parties !Leader |- | bgcolor="#556627" | | align="left" |[[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|National Liberation Front]] (FLN) |Djamel Ould Abbès |- | bgcolor="green" | | align="left" |[[National Rally for Democracy (Algeria)|National Rally for Democracy]] (RND) |Ahmed Ouyahia |- | | align="left" | Rally for Hope for Algeria (TAJ) Front]] (FFS) |Abdelmalek Bouchafa |- | bgcolor="red" | | align="left" |[[Workers' Party (Algeria)|Workers' Party]] (PT) |[[Louisa Hanoune]] |- | | align="left" |[[Movement of Society for Peace]] (MSP) |Abderrazak Mokri |- | bgcolor="green" | | align="left" |Algeria for All – Independent List (Alif) | |} Parties boycotting the elections include Talaie El-Houriat and Jil Jadid, whilst the Democratic and Social Union remains unauthorised. ==Results== {|class=wikitable style=text-align:right |- !colspan=2|Party !Votes !% !Seats !+/- |- |bgcolor=#556627| ||align=left|[[National Liberation revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=March 2011}} {{BLP sources|date=March 2011}} {{autobiography|date=April 2011}} }}
{{Infobox person | name =Andrea Elizabeth Michaels | image = Andrea Accepting AwardCropped3.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Andrea Michaels at the Special Event Convention in 2005. | birth_name = Andrea Elizabeth Gerson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|12|14}} | birth_place = [[Rab]], Croatia | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of California at Los Angeles]] | occupation = Event producer, business owner, author and speaker | organization = Extraordinary Events | known_for = | notable_works = | net_worth = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = {{URL|www.extraordinaryevents.net}} | footnotes = }} '''Andrea Elizabeth Michaels''' (née Gerson; born December 14, 1943) is an American meeting and event producer, author and speaker.<ref name=Stepping>Wright, David, ''Stepping Stones to Success - Experts Share Strategies for Mastering Business, Life and Relationships - with Deepak Chopra, Jack Canfield, Andrea Michaels and Dr. Denis Waitley''. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 237-248.</ref> As founder of an international event production company, Extraordinary Events, Michaels and her company produce large corporate events. She is an original member of the special events industry Hall of Fame<ref>Baragona, Carolyn, "Spotlight Award/Hall of Fame Inductees," ''Event Solutions'' magazine, December, 2002.</ref> and the author of a business biography,<ref name=reflect>>Michaels, Andrea, ''Reflections of a Successful Wallflower - Lessons in Business; Lessons in Life.'' Denver: Outskirts Press, 2010.</ref> and is featured in three [[anthologies]].
== Early life == Andrea Michaels was born in the [[Arbe concentration camp]] (today [[Rab]], [[Croatia]], on the northern shore of the [[Adriatic Sea]]) to Lelja Kauders (b. Zagreb, Yugoslavia, August 25, 1923 – d. Los Angeles California, May 30, 2009).<ref>Tributes.com/show/Lelja-Gerson</ref><ref name=ben7879>Wright, David, ''Yes You Can! Reaching Your Potential While Achieving Greatness - with Dr. Warren Bennis, Andrea Michaels and Jim Rohn''. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 77-88.</ref> Michaels and her mother, along with her mother's [[Jewish]] parents, Paul (Palvo) Kauders and Elza Ackerman Kauders, escaped in a small boat across the Adriatic to Italy.<ref name="ben7879"/> Michaels lived in Italy to the age of four with her grandparents until her mother, who had married an American pilot, sent for her to come live in America.<ref name="ben7879"/> The marriage ended, and after Michaels arrived in America, her mother married Peter Gerson, who adopted Andrea and moved the family from [[Silverlake, California]], to [[Hollywood]].<ref name="ben7879"/> When Michaels was ten, the family moved to [[Burbank, California]].<ref name="ben7879"/>
An only child Michaels graduated from [[Burbank High School (Burbank, California)|Burbank High School]] in 1961.<ref>http://www.classmates.com/places/school/school/3516/m?startYear=1900&endYear=9999&communityId=3516</ref> Michaels attended the [[University of California at Berkeley]] in 1961 and 1962, transferring to the [[University of California at Los Angeles]] (UCLA) before marrying Bob Spritz on February 1, 1964.<ref name="ben7879"/> The marriage lasted ten years, and they had a son, Jon (b. July 24, 1970).<ref name=reflect/> After her divorce from Spritz, she changed her last name as well as that of her son's to "Michaels."<ref name=reflect/> Michaels returned to UCLA in 1970 and earned a degree, with honors, in [[Psychology]].<ref>2002 Hall of Fame, NAWBOLA.org./About_Us/2002_hof.php</ref>
== Early career == Instead of pursuing a career in Psychology, Michaels began working with the Ron Rubin Orchestras in 1973.<ref>Barnett, Maggie, "Spectacular Events Keep Encino Firm in Demand," Features Section, Los Angeles Times, November 23, 1999.</ref> During that time, she became interested in the [[event planning]] business when there was no formalized industry. She produced her first event in 1978—-a [[Anniversary|bicentennial]] celebration for Marsh McClellan Insurance Company. By 1982, the company had been restructured and renamed Michaels, Rubin and Associates.<ref name=ben7879 /> Michaels and Rubin dissolved their relationship in December 1988, and on that same day, Extraordinary Events was launched.<ref>"Coffee With Andrea Michaels - Meetings And Conventions". Meetings-conventions.com. 2010-08-01. http://www.meetings-conventions.com/articles/coffee-with-andrea-michaels/a35650.aspx. Retrieved 2011-02-09.</ref><ref>Barnett, Maggie, "Spectacular Events Keep Encino Firm in Demand," Features Section, ''Los Angeles Times'', November 23, 1999. Found online as an abstract at [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/46600664.html?dids=46600664:46600664&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+23%2C+1999&author=MAGGIE+BARNETT&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=VALLEY+BUSINESS+%2F+ADVANCING+WOMEN%3A+PROFILES+OF+SUCCESS%3B+Spectacular+Events+Keep+Encino+Firm+in+Demand%3B+Entertainment%3A+Staging+big+productions+for+major+companies+is+a+hectic+but+profitable+venture+for+one+Valley+entrepreneur.&pqatl=google Los Angeles Times archives]. Accessed March 17, 2011.</ref> At that time, Michaels began to bring to the corporate world the spectaculars that had been produced on football fields, Disneyland and in entertainment venues<ref name=Stepping /> by the late [[Tommy Walker (events director)|Tommy Walker]] and the late [[Robert (Bob) Jani]].
== Later career == Extraordinary Events has specialized in planning and producing corporate events globally including Europe, Asia, Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean, Africa, Australia and New Zealand.<ref name=ben7879 /> In 2006, ''Special Events'' magazine listed Extraordinary Events as one of the "Top 50 Event Planning Companies."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eddiedeensranch.com/press/5th_annual_50_top_event_plan.pdf|title=www.eddiedeensranch.com/press/5th_annual_50_top_event_plan.pdf<!--INSERT TITLE-->|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>Hurley, Lisa, "5th Annual 50 Top Event Planning Companies List," ''Special Events'' magazine, September 12, 2006, pages 45-50.</ref> The [[Los Angeles Business Journal]] named it Number 28 on its list of the "Fastest Growing Private Companies"<ref>{{cite Michaels and her company began to incorporate charitable activities into its events with the rebuilding of an elementary school in Leona Vicario, Mexico, with client CEMEX, a concrete manufacturer, in 2005. The ''Los Angeles Business Journal''<ref name=labj>{{citation |url = http://www.aooevents.com/press/LABusinessJournal_Jan07.pdf |format = PDF |accessdate = 2011-02-09 |title = Event Heaven |author = Emily Bryson York |date = 8 January 2007 |publisher = Los Angeles Business Journal |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110707151622/http://www.aooevents.com/press/LABusinessJournal_Jan07.pdf |archive-date = 2011-07-07 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> and ''Financial and Insurance Meetings '' magazine<ref>{{cite web|author =Lisa Hurley |url=http://meetingsnet.com/0401-giving-back-teambuilding/ |title=Do-Good Events | Today's teambuilding events are about giving back |publisher=Meetingsnet.com |date=2009-04-01 |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> covered the event.
Michaels and Extraordinary Events have won the following awards: * 34 ''Special Events'' magazine Gala Awards<ref name=Bushido>Wright, David, ''Bushido Business - The Fine Art of the Modern Professional - with Tom Hopkins, Andrea Michaels, Brian Tracy and Stephen M.R. Covey. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 65-76.</ref> * 2 ''Special Events'' magazine Gala Awards of Excellence<ref name=Stepping /> * 2 WOW Awards<ref name=Bushido /> * 1 Meeting Planners International Paragon Award<ref name=event>{{cite web|url=http://www.event-solutions.com/andrea_michaels |title=Andrea Michaels |publisher=Event Solutions |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> * 2 Society of Incentive and Travel Executives Crystal Awards<ref name=Bushido /><ref>{{cite web|editor = Barbara Scofidio |url=http://meetingsnet.com/corporatemeetingsincentives/incentives/role_models/meetings_toast_010107/ |title=winners of SITE's Crystal Awards |publisher=Meetingsnet.com |date=2007-01-01 |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> * 3 EIBTM Awards<ref name=Bushido/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conworld.net/index.php/Europe/only-1-week-left-to-enter-prestigious-meetings-and-incentive-industry-awards.html |title=Only 1 Week left to enter prestigious Meetings and Incentive Industry Awards |publisher=Conworld.net |date=2009-09-08 |accessdate=2011-02-09| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101226110957/http://www.conworld.net/index.php/Europe/only-1-week-left-to-enter-prestigious-meetings-and-incentive-industry-awards.html| archivedate= 26 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> * 1 ''Successful Meetings'' Super Six Award<ref>"And the Winners Are...2004-12-01," ''Successful Meetings'', December 1, 2004.</ref> * National Association for Women in Business Hall of Fame 2002<ref name=nawb>{{cite web |url=http://www.nawbola.org/about_us/2002_hof.php |title=2002 Hall of Fame |publisher=Nawbola.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410221531/http://www.nawbola.org/about_us/2002_hof.php |archive-date=2011-04-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * ''Event Solutions'' Magazine Hall of Fame 2002<ref name=event/><ref>Baragona, Carolyn, "Spotlight Awards/Hall of Fame Inductees," ''Event Solutions'', December, 2002.</ref>

They are: ''Stepping Stones to Success'',<ref name=Stepping /> featuring Deepak Chopra, Jack Canfield, Andrea Michaels and Dr. Denis Waitley; ''Yes You Can! R. Covey.
