{{More citations needed|date=March 2010}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Cassie L. Chadwick | image_name = Chadwick-elizabeth-bigley-1904.jpg | image_alt = | image_caption = [[Cabinet card]] image of Cassie Chadwick from 1904{{cite book |last=Crosbie |first=John S. |title=The Incredible Mrs. Chadwick: The Most Notorious Woman of Her Age |location=Toronto |publisher=McGraw-Hill Ryerson |year=1975 |isbn=0-07-082194-1 }} | birth_name = Elizabeth Bigley | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1857|10|10}} | birth_place = [[Eastwood, Ontario|Eastwood]], [[United Province of Canada]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1907|10|10|1857|10|10}} | death_place = [[Columbus, Ohio]] | cause = | alias = Elizabeth Cunard
Emily Heathcliff
Lydia DeVere
Lydia Springsteen
Marie LaRose
Cassie Hoover
Cassie Chadwick
Cassie L. Chadwick | motive = Money | charge = [[forgery]]
seven counts forgery and seven counts [[Conspiracy (crime)#Conspiracy in the United States|conspiracy]] | conviction = 9½ years | conviction_penalty =14 years prison and $70,000 fine | conviction_status = Dead Columbus Ohio State Penitentiary | occupation = Clairvoyant/Fortune teller
[[Pimp|Madam]] | spouse = Dr. Wallace S. Springsteen
John R. Scott
Dr. Leroy S. Chadwick | parents = Dan Bigley
Annie Bigley | children = Emil Hoover }} '''Cassie L. Chadwick''' (10 October 1857 – 10 October 1907) is the [[Infamy|infamous]] name used by a [[Canadians|Canadian]] woman who defrauded several U.S. banks out of millions of dollars by claiming to be an illegitimate daughter and heiress of [[Andrew Carnegie]]. ==Early life== She was born '''Elizabeth Bigley''' on 10 October 1857 in [[Eastwood, Ontario]] Her parents, Dan and Annie, owned a small farm in Eastwood. She had three sisters: Alice, Mary, and Emily, and a brother, Bill. Her father worked for the [[Grand Trunk Railway]] as a section boss and was often away from the homestead. "Betsy", as she was known to her family, was known to daydream and tell fibs as a child. At the age of 14, Chadwick went to [[Woodstock, Ontario]], Canada. There she opened a bank account with a dubious letter of inheritance from an "unknown" uncle in England and a small amount of cash. While there, Chadwick passed several worthless cheques to various merchants. In 1870, she was arrested in Woodstock for [[forgery]]. She was released due to her age and on the grounds of [[Mental Disorder (Insanity) Defense|insanity]]. Following a three-year absence from Eastwood, she returned to discover her sister Alice had married Bill York, a carpenter from [[Cleveland, Ohio]], in 1875. Alice had moved to Cleveland with her new husband. Chadwick promptly boarded a train and headed south for the United States of America. ==Start in the U.S.== After a brief stay with her sister and brother-in-law, she rented the lower floor of a house at 149 Garden Street, Cleveland from a Mrs. Brown. Chadwick, claiming to be widowed, assumed the mystic name '''Madame Lydia DeVere'''. She set up shop as a [[clairvoyant]] with funds from a bank loan on her sister and brother-in-law's furniture. In 1882, as Lydia DeVere, she married Dr. Wallace S. Springsteen in Cleveland, Ohio. The couple exchanged vows before a [[Justice of the Peace]] on 21 November 1882. She took the name '''Mrs. Lydia Springsteen''' and moved into the doctor's house at 3 Garden Street. A photograph and story appeared in Cleveland's newspaper, ''[[The Plain Dealer]]''. The newspaper article led her sister, Alice York, and various trades-people to the home of Dr. Springsteen, demanding payment for debts his wife had accumulated. After Dr. Springsteen confirmed the stories about her past, he threw her out of the house. Dr. Springsteen filed for divorce (which was granted early in 1883) and settled her debts. Chadwick again established herself as a clairvoyant in Cleveland. As '''Madame Marie LaRose''', she met her next husband. In 1883, she married John R. Scott, a farmer from [[Trumbull County, Ohio]]. She convinced Mr. Scott to sign a [[prenuptial]] agreement, citing abuse from her first husband. After four years of farm life, she went, prenuptial in hand, to a lawyer in [[Youngstown, Ohio]]. She left a sworn statement confessing [[Adultery#Other consequences|adultery]] and directed her lawyer to file for divorce. ==First U.S. fraud trial== In 1889 she again resorted to forgery. Chadwick was convicted and sentenced to 9½ years in a [[Prison|penitentiary]] in [[Toledo, Ohio]]. She was paroled four years later in 1893 and returned to Cleveland, Ohio.{{cite news |title=Hoax of Heiress Ruined Bankers |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1755&dat=19550130&id=0eQhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=82QEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3685,5921429 |newspaper=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]] |date=January 30, 1955 |page=27}} ==Chadwick's third husband== Upon returning in 1893 to Cleveland, she assumed the name '''Mrs. Cassie Hoover'''. She opened a [[brothel]] on the city's near west side. At the brothel, she met her next husband, a wealthy widower named Dr. Leroy Chadwick. Knowing of the doctor's recent loss, Chadwick played the part of a genteel widow, "Mrs. Hoover," who ran a respectable boarding house for women. When Dr. Chadwick responded that the establishment was a well-known brothel, "Mrs. Hoover" fainted. Once revived, she claimed that she would never run such an establishment. She begged the Doctor to immediately take her from the building, lest anyone think she was complicit in its operation. ==As Cassie Chadwick== [[File:Euclid Avenue Mansion of Cassie Chadwick on Cleveland's Millionaire's Row.jpg|thumb|275px|The [[Euclid Avenue (Cleveland, Ohio)|Euclid Avenue]] residence of Cassie Chadwick]] In 1897 she married Dr. Chadwick. During her time as the wife of the highly respected Dr. Chadwick, it is unclear whether he knew that she had given birth to a son, Emil Hoover. Also, it is unclear whether Dr. Chadwick knew that Emil was in the care of one of the women at the brothel. She was very good at masking her identity and that of her son. In court records, she identified herself as single with no children when charged with forgery. However, in the [[1900 United States Census|1900 United States census]] (District 97, Cleveland, [[Cuyahoga County]] Ohio), she identified herself as '''Cassie Chadwick''', born 3 February 1862 in Pennsylvania. Her son Emil was enumerated as Emil Chadwick, born September 1886 in Canada. Following the Carnegie con, Emil Hoover was identified in the newspapers as her son. Chadwick's spending habits exceeded those of her well-heeled neighbours along Cleveland's [[Euclid Avenue (Cleveland, Ohio)|Euclid Avenue]], then known as "Millionaires' Row". Instead of being welcomed into the exclusive enclave of the [[Rockefellers]], the [[Mark Hanna|Hannas]], the Hays and the Mathers, Chadwick was thought of as a curious woman who tried in vain to buy the favours of some of the wealthiest families in the nation. When invited to social events, it was only out of obligation to Dr. Chadwick. ==The Carnegie con== Following her marriage to Dr. Chadwick in 1897, Chadwick began her largest, most successful con game: that of establishing herself as [[Andrew Carnegie]]'s daughter. During a visit to [[New York City]], she asked one of her husband's acquaintances, a [[lawyer]] named Dillon, to take her to the home of Andrew Carnegie. In reality, she just visited his housekeeper ostensibly trying to check credentials. When she came back, she dropped a paper. Dillon took it up and noticed it was a [[promissory note]] for $2 million with Carnegie's signature. When Dillon promised to keep her secret, she "revealed" that she was Carnegie's [[illegitimate child]]. Carnegie was supposedly so wracked with guilt that he showered huge amounts of money on her. She also claimed that there was $7 million in promissory notes tucked away in her Cleveland home, and she was to inherit $400 million upon Carnegie's death. Dillon arranged a [[safe deposit box]] for her document. This information leaked to the financial markets in northern Ohio, and [[banking|banks]] began to offer their services. For the next eight years she used this fake background to obtain loans that eventually totalled between $10 and $20 million. She correctly guessed that no one would ask Carnegie about an illegitimate daughter for fear of embarrassing him. Also, the loans came with [[usury|usurious]] interest rates, so high in fact, that the bankers wouldn't admit to granting them. She forged [[securities]] in Carnegie's name for further proof. Bankers assumed that Carnegie would vouch for any debts, and that they would be fully repaid once Carnegie died. With this money, Chadwick began to live a very lavish lifestyle. She bought diamond necklaces, enough clothes to fill 30 closets, and a gold organ. She became known as "the Queen of Ohio." In November 1904, she received a $190,000 loan from Herbert B. Newton, a [[Brookline, Massachusetts]] banker. Newton was shocked when he learned of the other loans Chadwick had received, and called his loan in. Chadwick could not pay and the bank sued. At the time, she had accumulated debts equal to $5 million. It was also discovered that a number of securities being held for her in various banks were worthless. When Carnegie was later asked about her, he denied ever knowing her, and further stated he hadn't signed a note in more than 30 years. Chadwick fled to New York, but was soon arrested at her apartment at the Hotel Breslin and taken back to Cleveland. When she was arrested, she was wearing a money belt containing over $100,000. Leroy Chadwick and his adult daughter hastily left Cleveland for a European tour when the scandal broke. However, he did file for divorce before leaving on the tour. The news sent shockwaves through the Cleveland banking community. One bank, Citizen's National Bank of [[Oberlin, Ohio|Oberlin]], which had loaned her $800,000, suffered a massive [[bank run|run]] that forced it into bankruptcy.{{citation needed|date=March 2012}} ==Second U.S. fraud trial== Andrew Carnegie attended her trial, wishing to see the woman who had successfully conned the nation's bankers into believing that she was his heir. Other attendees included members of the very Millionaires' Row families from whom she had tried so hard to gain acceptance. The trial was a media circus. On 10 March 1905 a Cleveland court sentenced her to 14 years in prison and a fine of $70,000 for conspiracy to bankrupt the Citizen's National Bank and conspiracy against the government (Citizen's Bank, as a federally chartered bank, was an agent of the federal government). ==Prison== On 1 January 1906, Chadwick was sent to the [[Ohio Penitentiary|Ohio State Penitentiary]] in Columbus. She brought with her trunks of goods for her prison cell, including clothing, photographs, and furniture. The prison warden allowed this due to her celebrity status. As her health deteriorated, Chadwick began writing explicit instructions for her funeral. She instructed her son Emil to send a portion of her hidden funds to Canada for the purchase of a tombstone for the family plot. Chadwick suffered a "nervous collapse" 17 September 1907 leaving her blind. The New York Times reported that 9 October 1907 Chadwick was suffering from heart and stomach problems and as Dr. Helmick stated was "much worse." ==Death== Chadwick died on her birthday in the Columbus penitentiary 10 October 1907 (aged 50). The funeral service was officiated by Reverend F.W. Thompson of College Avenue Methodist Church. Her interment was 16 October 1907 in the Episcopal Cemetery (present day Woodstock Anglican Cemetery "A" section VanSittart Avenue) [[Woodstock, Ontario]] in her birthplace Canada. Chadwick's tombstone reads "Elizabeth Bigley wife of L.S. Chadwick, M.D. 1859 - 1907". ==Fallout== For a time, the Chadwick Mansion on [[Euclid Avenue (Cleveland, Ohio)|Euclid Avenue]] (at East 82nd Street) became a tourist destination. In the early 1920s, it was torn down for the construction of the Euclid Avenue Temple (now Liberty Hill Baptist Church). Other people were involved in the tangled web Chadwick spun. Her housekeeper, Mrs. Mary Londraville, took a satchel apparently for Chadwick's son that the [[Receivership|receiver]] wanted as he thought it to have contained valuables. There was a related death. ==In popular culture== She was the subject of the Canadian TV movie ''Love & Larceny'' (1985), where the role of Betsy Bigley was played by [[Jennifer Dale]]. In the Canadian TV series, [[Murdoch Mysteries]], Cassie Chadwick was played by [[Wendy Crewson]]. ==References== {{Reflist | colwidth = 30em | refs = {{cite web |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/409664101.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+12%2C+1905&author=&pub=Chicago+Daily+Tribune+%281872-1922%29&edition=&startpage=1&desc=CASSIE+CHADWICK+IS+FOUND+GUILTY. |title=CASSIE CHADWICK IS FOUND GUILTY. |date=12 March 1905 | format= |publisher=[[Chicago Daily Tribune]]|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/403649791.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+21%2C+1907&author=&pub=Chicago+Daily+Tribune+%281872-1922%29&edition=&startpage=2&desc=CHADWICK+LOANS+OF+JUTTE+CASH%3F |title=CHADWICK LOANS OF JUTTE CASH? |date=21 October 1907 | format= |publisher=[[Chicago Daily Tribune]]|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web | url = http://www.cbc.ca/documentaries/doczone/2009/truthaboutliars/canada.html | title = Great Canadian Liars | author = | date = | month = | year = | publisher = [[CBC Television]] | archiveurl = | archivedate = | accessdate = 23 February 2011 | quote = | postscript = . }} {{cite web |url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~dcoop/wdskanglican/wdana207.htm |title=Picture of Chadwick's tombstone Woodstock Anglican Cemetery "A" section VanSittart Ave |author= |date= |publisher=[[Ancestry.com]] |accessdate=29 November 2009}} [[The Globe (Toronto newspaper)|''The Globe'']] (Toronto), 17 September 1907, page 11. [[The Globe (Toronto newspaper)|''The Globe'']] (Toronto), 12 October 1907, page 07. [[The Globe (Toronto newspaper)|''The Globe'']] (Toronto), 15 October 1907, page 03. {{cite web |url=http://collectionscanada.gc.ca/ourl/res.php?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&url_tim=2011-01-20T21%3A13%3A13Z&url_ctx_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&rft_dat=13483158&rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fcollectionscanada.gc.ca%3Aamicus |title=AMICUS No. 13483158 |author=[[Library and Archives Canada]] |date= |accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/10/11/104997127.pdf |title=CASSIE CHADWICK DIES IN PRISON |date=10 October 1907 | format=PDF |work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/10/10/104996740.pdf |title=CASSIE CHADWICK WORSE. |date=10 October 1907 |format=PDF |work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/09/17/101728644.pdf |title=CASSIE CHADWICK ILL. |date=17 September 1907 |format=PDF |work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1904/12/11/archives/chadwick-paper-out-is-over-19000000-includes-16496000-under-andrew.html?sq=Cassie+Chadwick&scp=8&st=cse |title=CHADWICK PAPER OUT IS OVER $19,000,000; Includes $16,496,000 Under Andrew Carnegie's Name, RECKONED ON HIS DEATH Mr. Carnegie to Be Subpoenaed -- Reynolds Gives Up "Securities " -- Woman's Indictment Expected. |date=11 December 1904 |format=PDF |work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/12/16/120273739.pdf |title=IDENTIFY MRS. CHADWICK AS MME. DEVERE, FORGER; Prison Employes Face Her -- Beckwith Not Sure She's a Fraud. |date=16 December 1904 |format=PDF |work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/12/22/118949902.pdf |title=TRACING CHADWICK SATCHEL.; Receiver on Trail of More Missing Possessions of the Woman. |date=22 December 1904 |format=PDF |work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/12/04/118949430.pdf |title=AID FOR MRS. CHADWICK, BUT ARRESTS THREATENED; Famous Man Will Pay, It Is Said, to Avoid Scandal. |date=4 December 1904 |format=PDF |work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2011}} {{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/12/06/102418822.pdf |title=WANT CARNEGIE AS CHADWICK WITNESS; To Subpoena Him in Bank Case -- Notes for $1,250,000 Bear His Name. RECEIVER TO CALL ON HIM Denial Issued by Mr. Carnegie -- President of Wrecked Bank Talks of Mrs. Chadwick. |date=6 December 1904 |format=PDF |work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2011}} [[Toronto Star|''The Evening Star'']] (Toronto), 11 October 1907, page 15. }} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051222053612/http://www.lkwdpl.org/wihohio/chad-cas.htm Women in History] *[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~dcoop/wdskanglican/wdana207.htm Picture of Chadwick's tombstone Woodstock Anglican Cemetery "A" section VanSittart Avenue.] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chadwick, Cassie}} [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1907 deaths]] [[Category:People from Oxford County, Ontario]] [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:Canadian fraudsters]] [[Category:Canadian people imprisoned abroad]] [[Category:Canadian people who died in prison custody]] [[Category:Canadian-American culture in Ohio]] [[Category:Prisoners who died in Ohio detention]] [[Category:History of Cleveland]] [[Category:People convicted of fraud]] [[Category:19th-century Canadian criminals]]

revision.text:
:''This article is about the Buddhist monastery in [[Amdo]] or the [[Gannan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture]], in western [[China]]. There is also a '''Cho-ne Gon Monastery''' belonging to the [[Kagyu]] sect in ancient [[Kham]] or [[Jomda County]], [[China]]. {{Infobox Tibetan Buddhist monastery |name =Chone Monastery |image = |image size = |alt = |caption = |t= ཅོ་ནེ་དགོན་ཆེན |w= |to = |ipa= |z= |thdl= |e= Chone Gonchen Ganden Shedrubling, Choni Monastery |tc=卓尼 |s= |p=Zhuōní |pushpin_map = China |coordinates = {{coord|34.5963|||N|103.5048|||E|type:landmark_region:CN|display=inline,title}} |map_caption = Location within China |mapsize = 250 |location_country = China |location= [[Jone County]], [[Gannan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture]], [[Gansu]], [[China]] |founded_by = Drogon Ghogyel [[Phakpa]] and his [[Mongol]] patron, [[Kublai Khan]] |founded = 1269 |date_renovated = |sect = [[Gelug]] |altitude = 2,610 m |lineage= |dedicated_to = [[Tsongkhapa]] |head_lama = |colleges= |no._of_monks = 120 |architecture = |festivals= Cham-nyon-wa |footnotes = }}
{{Tibetan Buddhism}} '''Chone Monastery''' (Tibetan: Wylie: ; Chinese: Jonê; Pinyin: Zhuōní), also '''Chone Gonchen Ganden Shedrubling''', or '''Choni Monastery''' was originally a [[Sakya]] monastery. It is situated adjacent to Chone Town, [[Jonê County]], [[Gannan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture]], [[Gansu Province]], China, at an altitude of about 2,610 m (8,563 ft).
==History== :"There are traditions of Tibetan soldiers left behind [after the late 10th century] at several border outposts, such as Chone, where they established viable settlements, and of the remaining Tibetan conscript troops, called the Wun Mo, carving out considerable territory for themselves until they were perhaps absorbed into that amalgam of people of Tibetan stock, which came to form the [[Hsi Hsia Kingdom]] (982—1224)."<ref>Snellgrove & Richardson (1995), p. 111.</ref>
Chone Monastery was founded in 1269 by Drogon Ghogyel [[Phakpa]] (1235–1280) and his [[Mongol]] patron, [[Kublai Khan]] or (Qubilai Qan), in 1269 CE as a Sakya monastery.
Chone Monastery was part of a separate kingdom formed, according to legend, after its invasion by Chinese warriors who migrated across the mountains from [[Szechuan]] conquering the local tribes in 1404. The [[Yongle Emperor]] (May 2, 1360 – August 12, 1424) named one of them hereditary chief, bestowing the name of "Yang" and an imperial seal upon them and the prince established a palace on the north bank of the [[Tao River]]. The Yang family, continued to rule over 48 unruly Tibetan clans in Chon-ne as a semi-independent kingdom from the early 15th century for 23 generations, until 1928, when it was placed under the control of the [[Lanchow]] government.<ref>Cabot (2003, pp. 157-158.</ref>
Phakpa, who was trusted to rule Tibet by the Mongol Emperor of the Yuan Dynasty, Kublai Khan, visited the area which, until that time was mainly under the influence of the ancient Bon religion. In 1459 the monastery was converted to the [[Gelug]] sect by Choje Rinchen Lingpo.<ref>Osada et al (2004), pp. 186-187.</ref>
Its colleges were established in the 18th century by Kunkyen Jigme Wangpo. with the School of Dialectics ('''Tsenyl Dratsang''') being founded in 1714 and the Tantric ([[Vajrayana]]) college ('''Gyupa Dratsang''') in 1729.
==Description== The monastery is situated near a bend in the rushing, clear, Tao River surrounded by high wooded mountains, adjacent to the fairly large [[Chone Town]] which has a mixed population of Tibetans and Chinese, though the Chinese now predominate.<ref>Dorje (2009), p. 813.</ref> In 1923, the village had "approximately four hundred Tibetan families and had changed very little since its founding six centuries before."<ref>Cabot (2003, p. 157.</ref>
:"At the entrance to the [monastery] complex is a Chinese pavilion, containing a [[stele]] inscribed in Tibetan and Chinese which commemorates the history of the monastery and its expansion under Manchu patronage during the 18th century."<ref>Dorje (2009), p. 812.</ref>
Within the grounds are six large buildings - only one of which has been ruined (to the left). The Assembly Hall is in the centre with the Gyupa Dratsang is to the right and behind are the Tsenyi Dratsang, the Chora (Debating Garden), the Taknyi Lhakhang which is dedicated to [[Hevajra]] and the Sariwa Lhakhang. The monastery was famed for its 1773 [[woodblock printing|woodblock]] editions of the [[Kangyur]] and [[Tangyur]], copies of which still exist though, unfortunately, the original woodblocks have been damaged beyond repair.<ref>Dorje (2009), p. 812.</ref>
When the monastery was visited by [[Janet Elliott Wulsin]] and her husband, Frederick Wulsin, in 1923, Chone Monastery had survived numerous earthquakes. On the main gate was an inscription composed by the Kangxi Emperor (4 May 1654 – 20 December 1722) in 1710 which read: "Bestowed by Imperial Command, Temple of Tranquillity" as a favour to a local lama who had visited him in Beijing and returned with 3,000 [[taels]] (each approximately 37 grams) of silver, which he used to erect buildings in the monastery. At one time there were 172 buildings including ten chanting halls within the monastery and 3,800 monks. By 1923 the population was only about 700.<ref>Cabot (2003, p. 158.</ref>
:"Inside the oldest of Choni's chanting halls, dating back five hundred years, Janet and Frederick discovered the enormous gilded figure of [[Tsongkhapa]] with his two disciples. Legend had it that Tsongkhapa had appeared on the stone altar of the monastery in 1714, and, after addressing the crowd on the greatness of his church, became transfigured and ascended into heaven."<ref>Cabot (2003, p. 159.</ref>
The monastery now has only about 120 monks which gives it a rather deserted atmosphere.<ref>Dorje (2009), p. 813.</ref>
==Festival== On the sixth day of the sixth moon (in August/September) the spectacular ''Cham-ngyon-wa'', or "Old Dance," is celebrated at the monastery, representing the souls of the departed.<ref>Cabot (2003, pp. 159-163.</ref>
==Footnotes== {{Reflist|2}}
==References== *Cabot, Mabel H. (2003). ''Vanished Kingdoms: A Woman Explorer in Tibet, China & Mongolia, 1921-1925'', pp. 148–157. Aperture Publishers in association with the Peabody Museum, Harvard. {{ISBN|978-1-931788-18-2}}. *Dorje, Gyurme (2009). ''Footprint Tibet Handbook''. Footprint Publications, Bath, England. {{ISBN|978-1-906098-32-2}}. *Osada, Yukiyasu, Gavin Allwright and Atsushi Kanamaru. (2004). ''Mapping the Tibetan World''. Kotan Publishing, Tokyo, Japan. {{ISBN|0-9701716-0-9}}. *Snellgrove, David & Hugh Richardson (1995). ''A Cultural History of Tibet''. (Revised edition) Shambhala Publications, Boston. {{ISBN|1-57062-102-0}} (pbk).
==Further reading== *Rock, Joseph F. (1928). ''Life Among the Lamas of Choni''. [[Joseph F. Rock]]. National Geographic Magazine. November 1928, pp. 569–619.
==External links== * "Tibet Outside the TAR: Chone Dzong." Tibet Environmental Watch [http://www.tew.org/totar/totar.chone.html] * TibetInfoNet "Tibet 2008: Reported Unrest and Related Incidents." [http://www.tibetinfonet.net/newsticker/entriesprovince_id=19&location_id=146&prefecture_id=32]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport tournament | name =Community Effort Orlando (CEO) | image =File:Community Effort Orlando logo.png | caption = | sport = various [[fighting game]]s | location = [[Orlando, Florida]] | month_played = June | establishment = 2010 | defunct = | number = 1 annually | administrator = Alex Jebailey | format = | current_champion = ''[[Street Fighter V|SFV]]'': Tokido
''[[Super Smash Bros. Wii U|SSB Wii U]]'': ANTi
''[[Mortal Kombat X|MKX]]'': SonicFox
''[[Pokkén Tournament|Pokkén]]'': Suicune Master
''[[Ultimate Marvel vs. Capcom 3|UMVC3]]'': KaneBlueRiver
''[[Tekken 7]]'':Anakin
　''[[SSBM]]'': [[Hungrybox]]
''[[Guilty Gear Xrd Revelator]]'': Dogura
''[[Killer Instinct]]'': Thompxson
''[[USF4]]'': [[Wolfkrone]] | final_champion = }} '''Community Effort Orlando''' (often shortened to '''CEO''') is an annual [[fighting game]] event held in [[Orlando, Florida]]. Introduced in 2010 and organized by '''Alex Jebailey''', the event is known for its strong ties to the [[fighting game community]]. Fighting game players compete in a [[wrestling ring]] during the event's tournaments, and CEO has been a mainstay of the [[Capcom Pro Tour]] since its establishment in 2014. An annual side-event titled '''CEOtaku''' was initiated in 2015. ==Background== {{quotebox|width=25%|"I have no reason to ever leave Orlando. I went to school here, I grew up here, and I’ve always worked in Orlando. Now, because of CEO and all the other events I get to do, I get to travel, but I always come back to Orlando. It’s a great place."|–Alex Jebailey{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331802322815/community-effort-orlando-is-what-it-sounds-like|work=[[Red Bull GmbH|Red Bull]]|title=Community Effort Orlando is What it Sounds Like|last=Alphonse|first=Greg|date=2016-06-23}}}} Described in 2016 as one of the biggest [[fighting game community]] events in the United States by ''[[Red Bull GmbH|Red Bull]]'', CEO has been running annually since 2010 and has grown exponentially every year. Organized by Alex Jebailey, the event is known primarily for emphasizing community spirit. Jebailey's goal for CEO is to ensure the entertainment of all its attendees. The event has an "infamous" [[wrestling ring]] in which tournament players compete and those who reach the finals make "[[WWE]] style entrances". Jebailey himself has been interested in video game competition since 1993, when he won a local ''[[Street Fighter II Turbo]]'' tournament on the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]]. He has competed in various tournaments during the 1990s and 2000s, including ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' and ''[[Killer Instinct]]'' competitions, as well as professional [[trading card game]] contests. Here, he got the inspiration and experience to become a tournament organizer.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331745299968/casuals-alex-jebailey-florida-s-ceo-of-the-fgc|work=[[Red Bull GmbH]]|title=Casuals: Alex Jebailey, Florida's CEO of the FGC|last=Martin|first=Michael|date=2015-09-03}} Jebailey joined [[Iron Galaxy]] in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/03/28/ceo-2014-is-all-about-community|work=[[IGN]]|title=CEO 2014 is All About Community|last=Ingenito|first=Vince|date=2014-03-28}} ==History== ===2010–2013=== In 2010, there was a fighting game event that was "supposed to" happen in Orlando, but things did not come together until Alex Jebailey was assigned as Tournament Organizer three weeks prior to when the event was planned. He named the event 'Community Effort Orlando', managed the tournament brackets on his own, and ran the stream with one colleague. Florida was not known for having an active fighting game community, though the 2010 open tournament totaled 300 players. CEO was held on June 10–12 in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/05/18/how-one-man-won-10000-playing-mortal-kombat|work=[[IGN]]|title=How One Man Won $10,000 Playing Mortal Kombat|last=Chen|first=James|date=2011-05-18}} ''[[Orlando Business Journal]]'' reported in 2012 that CEO was growing steadily, having reached 1,600 attendees and 30,000 online viewers. Jebailey stated that his presence on social media such as [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] has allowed the event to grow in size.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/print-edition/2012/11/02/jebaileys-ceo-gaming-conference-growing.html|work=[[Orlando Business Journal]]|title=Jebailey’s CEO Gaming conference growing|last=Aboraya|first=Abraham|date=2012-11-02}} At this point, CEO was part of the "[[Road to Evo]]" series of major ranking events. CEO 2013 had over 1,800 attendees. The day after winning a CEO tournament, ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom 3]]'' player Noel Brown was arrested for domestic abuse after attacking a fellow tournament player.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/top-fighting-gamer-arrested-for-allegedly-hitting-his-e-635549540|work=[[Kotaku]]|title=Top Fighting Gamer Arrested For Allegedly Hitting His Ex-Girlfriend|last=Shreier|first=Jason|date=2013-07-01}} ===2014=== CEO was held on June 27–29 in 2014 and was one of the ten Premier Events of the first annual [[Capcom Pro Tour]], meaning that high-ranking players of the ''[[Ultra Street Fighter IV]]'' tournament at CEO could qualify for the [[2014 Capcom Cup]].{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/03/10/ready-fight-capcom-partners-with-twitch-for-year-round-street-fighter-league/|work=[[VentureBeat]]|title=Ready? Fight! Capcom partners with Twitch for year-round Street Fighter league|last=Grubb|first=Jeff|date=2014-03-10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/3/10/5490446/capcom-pro-tour-twitch-capcom-street-fighter-league|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|title=Twitch and Capcom teaming up for Street Fighter league Capcom Pro Tour|last=Sarkar|first=Samit|date=2014-03-10}} CEO 2014 was also sponsored by One Frame Link, and Jebailey sold CEO-themed T-shirts based on the various games played during the event in order to crowdfund the prize pool of each tournament. ===2015=== CEO, taking place on June 26–28, was one of the sixteen Capcom Pro Tour events of the 2015 season, and the winner of its ''Ultra Street Fighter IV'' tournament automatically qualified for the [[2015 Capcom Cup]]. Capcom revealed the first playable demo of ''[[Street Fighter V]]'' at CEO 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/street-fighter-v-ceo-2015/|work=[[Digital Trends]]|title=Capcom will be letting the public play Street Fighter V next month at CEO 2015 in Orlando|last=Wouk|first=Chris|date=2015-05-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/street-fighter-v-playable-at-june-event/|work=[[PC Gamer]]|title=Street Fighter V playable at June event|last=Dransfield|first=Ian|date=2015-05-25}} Held at the Wyndham Orlando Resort, CEO 2015 brought in over 3,000 attendees.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/news/2015/06/22/huge-gaming-tournament-to-bring-thousands-to.html|work=[[Orlando Business Journal]]|title=Huge gaming tournament to bring thousands to Orlando this weekend|last=Richardson|first=Matthew|date=2015-06-22}} At the CEO 2015 ''Ultra Street Fighter IV'' tournament, well-known players such as [[Infiltration (video gamer)|Infiltration]], [[Tokido]], [[Yusuke Momochi]], and [[Daigo Umehara]] were all eliminated before reaching the finals. The tournament was won by [[Kazunoko]], who beat 801 Strider in the winner's bracket semi-final and defeated [[Fuudo]] in the Grand Final.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331732139753/america-at-ceo-2015-close-but-no-cigar|work=[[Red Bull GmbH|Red Bull]]|title=America at CEO 2015: Close but no Cigar|last=Martin|first=Michael|date=2015-06-29}} As a response to the consistent success of ''[[Super Smash Bros.]]''-player [[Gonzalo "ZeRo" Barrios]] throughout the 2015 season, Jebailey gave out a prize to whoever could knock him out of the CEO 2015 tournament. As a response, ''[[Smashboards]]'' owner Chris "AlphaZealot" Brown added more money to the "bounty".{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/smash-bros-player-is-so-damn-good-theres-a-bounty-on-1705875804|work=[[Kotaku]]|title=Smash Bros. Player Is So Damn Good, There's Now A Bounty On His Head|last=Hernandez|first=Patricia|date=2015-05-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.technobuffalo.com/2015/05/21/smash-bros-player-good-enough-to-earn-a-bounty-on-his-head/|work=Techno Buffalo|title=Smash Bros. player good enough to earn a bounty on his head|last=Duwell|first=Ron|date=2015-05-21}} Regardless, ZeRo won the tournament, defeating [[Nairoby "Nairo" Quezada]] in the Grand Final.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/en/esports/stories/1331732624550/what-ceo-2015-tells-us-about-the-smash-bros-meta|work=[[Red Bull GmbH|Red Bull]]|title=What CEO 2015 tells us about the Smash Bros meta|last=Higgins|first=Chris|date=2015-07-01}} ===2016=== {{quotebox|width=25%|"I did what it took, and it costed a couple thousand dollars for the extra security, but if it helps people feel safer and have a better time it’s more than worth it to me."|–Alex Jebailey}} CEO 2016 took place two weeks after the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting|Orlando nightclub shooting]]. Jebailey quickly responded to people's worries regarding personal safety on [[social media]] that he would redouble the event's security. In an interview with ''Red Bull'', Jebailey stated that "We understand bad things happen in the world, but if I can spend a weekend with my community and get away from it... I can’t imagine anything better." CEO 2016, again a Capcom Pro Tour Premier Event, featured ten major fighting game tournaments, including ''Ultra Street Fighter IV'' side-to-side with ''[[Street Fighter V]]''. Jebailey stated in an interview that there was a large amount of interest in the older game within the Florida fighting game community.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331768511768/ceo-2016-lineup-announced-jebailey-explains|work=[[Red Bull GmbH|Red Bull]]|title=CEO 2016 Lineup Announced: Jebailey Explains|last=Rubens|first=Alex|date=2016-01-04}} ''Orlando Business Journal'' reported that the event had over 4,000 attendees from 46 states and more than 25 countries. Besides major tournaments of new games such as ''[[Pokkén Tournament]]'', ''[[King of Fighters XIV]]'', and ''[[Guilty Gear Xrd]]'', the event included a "free-to-play" [[video game arcade]] and a guest appearance of professional wrestlers [[Xavier Woods]] and [[Kenny Omega]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/news/2016/06/01/3-new-things-coming-to-orlandos-biggest-video-game.html|work=[[Orlando Business Journal]]|title=3 new things coming to Orlando's biggest video game tournament|last=Richardson|first=Matthew|date=2016-06-01}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestlinginc.com/wi/news/2016/0626/613054/xavier-woods-talks-loss-to-kenny-omega-at-ceo-2016/|work=[[Wrestlinginc.com]]|title=Xavier Woods Talks Loss To Kenny Omega At CEO 2016, Video Games Bringing Talent Together Backstage|last=Giri|first=Raj|date=2016-06-26}} ===2017=== Jebailey announced in July 2016 that CEO 2017 would move away from its traditional late-June date in order for the event to be held in a new venue. The event may even move to a different city.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/ceo-date-city-change-2017/|work=[[The Daily Dot]]|title=CEO may change dates and/or cities in 2017 as it searches for a new venue|last=Jurek|first=Steve|date=2016-07-09}} Later, CEO 2017 was announced to be held again in the [[Wyndham Resort]] in Orlando from June 16 to 18. The event featured tournaments for ''Street Fighter V'', ''Tekken 7'', ''Super Smash Bros Melee'', ''Super Smash Bros for Wii U'', ''[[Injustice 2]]'', ''Pokken Tournament'', ''Ultimate Marvel vs Capcom 3'', ''[[Killer Instinct (2013 video game)|Killer Instinct]]'', ''The King of Fighters XIV'', ''Guilty Gear Xrd'', and ''[[BlazBlue: Central Fiction]]''.{{cite web|url=https://pvplive.net/c/ceo-2017-schedule-revealed-melee-to-be-played-on-s|work=[[PVP Live]]|title=CEO 2017 Schedule Revealed, Melee to be Played on Saturday|last=Steiner|first=Dustin|date=2017-04-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.esportsinsider.com/2017/01/community-effort-orlando-reveal-games/|work=[[Esports Insider]]|title=Community Effort Orlando reveal games to be played at 2017 event|last=Ring|first=Oliver|date=2017-01-31}} [[Microsoft Studios]] announced at CEO 2017 that the 2013 version of ''Killer Instinct'' would be released on the [[Steam (software)|Steam platform]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/06/18/time-combo-breaker-killer-instinct-will-released-steam/|work=[[Bleeding Cool]]|title=Time For A Combo Breaker: ‘Killer Instinct’ Will Be Released On Steam|last=Sheehan|first=Gavin|date=2017-06-18}} ==CEOtaku== Jebailey set up a side event called CEOtaku in October 2015. A [[portmanteau]] of CEO and [[otaku]], the event focused specifically on Japanese 2D fighting games often referred to as "anime fighters". Such games have historically not gotten as much attention among the fighting game community. Jebailey got the idea of starting CEOtaku when he noticed that Florida features many [[anime convention]]s throughout any given year, and was inspired when he saw a side-event at [[Evo 2015]] dubbed "ANIMEvo".{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331742539800/ceotaku-the-anime-fgc-s-big-break|work=[[Red Bull GmbH|Red Bull]]|title=CEOtaku: The Anime FGC's Big Break|last=Womack|first=Barrett|date=2015-08-21}} CEOtaku has since become an annual event as well. ==Dreamland== In April 2017, Jebailey hosted CEO Dreamland, a ''[[Super Smash Bros.]]''-focused event featuring tournaments for each game in the series. The event attracted nearly 1,100 attendees, but failed to return its production cost. Jebailey blamed the lack of attendees in comparison to his annual CEO events on poor scheduling, as Dreamland took place on [[Easter]] weekend and coincided with the annual [[Star Wars Celebration]] at [[Walt Disney World]]. Following its near $20,000 [[USD]] loss, Dreamland is unlikely to return.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/esports/story/_/id/19243116/future-uncertain-ceo-dreamland-tournaments|work=[[ESPN]]|title=Future uncertain for CEO Dreamland tournaments|last=Wolf|first=Jacob|date=2017-04-26}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Competitive Super Smash Bros.}} {{Fighting game community}} [[Category:Fighting game tournaments]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2010]] [[Category:Annual events in Florida]] [[Category:Events in Orlando, Florida]] [[Category:Super Smash Bros. tournaments]] [[Category:June events]]

page.title: Criminal transmission of HIV in the United States

revision.text:
The '''criminal transmission of [[HIV]] in the [[United States]]''' varies among jurisdictions. More than thirty of the fifty states in the U.S. have prosecuted HIV-positive individuals for exposing another person to HIV. State laws criminalize different behaviors and assign different penalties. While pinpointing who infected who is scientifically impossible, a person diagnosed with HIV who is accused of infecting another while engaging in [[sexual intercourse]] is, in many jurisdictions, automatically committing a crime. A person donating HIV-infected organs, tissues, and blood can be prosecuted for transmitting the virus. Spitting or transmitting HIV-infected bodily fluids is a criminal offense in some states, particularly if the target is a prison guard. Some states treat the transmission of HIV, depending upon a variety of factors, as a [[felony]] and others as a [[misdemeanor]].
In October 2012, the HIV Medicine Association (HIVMA) of the [[Infectious Diseases Society of America]] (IDSA) called for the repeal of statutes that criminalize HIV-related behavior, writing: "Policies and laws that create HIV-specific crimes or that impose penalties for persons who are HIV-infected are unjust and harmful to public health around the world." It argued that such laws contribute to stigmatization and discrimination that inhibit diagnosis and result in "harsh sentencing for behaviors that pose little to no risk of HIV transmission." It advised that "All state and federal policies, laws and regulations ... be based on scientifically accurate information regarding HIV transmission routes and risk."<ref>{{cite web|title=HIVMA Urges Repeal of HIV-specific Criminal Statutes|url=http://www.hivma.org/uploadedFiles/HIVMA/FINAL%20HIVMA%20Policy%20Statement%20on%20HIV%20Criminalization.pdf|publisher=HIV Medicine Association|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref>
In 2017 the [[Center for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) stated that those who are on HIV medication can no longer transmit the virus, but the possibility for a person to not use a prescription and continue to infect others remains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-4953600/CDC-says-people-HIV-meds-transmit-virus.html|title=CDC declares that people on HIV medication cannot transmit the virus|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/risk/art/index.html|title=HIV Treatment as Prevention - HIV Risk and Prevention - HIV/AIDS - CDC|date=10 September 2018|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/those-undetectable-hiv-effectively-no-risk-transmitting-virus-cdc-says-n805916|title=Those with undetectable HIV at "effectively no risk" of transmitting virus, CDC says|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/hiv-medication-people-on-it-cannot-transmit-virus-cdc-treatment-aids-a7990286.html|title=HIV drugs now so effective people on them cannot transmit virus|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref> ==Federal law and policy==
===National HIV/AIDS strategy=== In July 2010, the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|White House]] announced a major change in its HIV/AIDS policy; the "National HIV/AIDS Strategy for the United States" stated that "the continued existence and enforcement of these types of laws [that criminalize HIV infection] run counter to scientific evidence about routes of HIV transmission and may undermine the public health goals of promoting HIV screening and treatment."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/sites/default/files/uploads/NHAS.pdf|title= National HIV/AIDS Strategy for the United States|page= 35|author=The White House Office of National AIDS Policy|date=July 2010|accessdate= December 6, 2012}}</ref> The administration's strategy cited a 2008 paper by Scott Burris and Edwin Cameron, a South African judge: "The use of criminal law to address HIV infection is inappropriate except in rare cases in which a person acts with conscious intent to transmit HIV and does so."<ref>[http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=182315 Scott Burris and Edwin Cameron, "The case against criminalization of HIV transmission", ''JAMA'' (2008)]. Retrieved December 6, 2012</ref>
In September 2010, the Center for HIV Law and Policy launched the Positive Justice Project, a campaign to combat HIV-related stigma and discrimination against people with HIV by the US criminal justice system.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Heywood|first1=Todd A.|title=New group seeks end to HIV-specific criminal laws|url=http://iowaindependent.com/44113/new-group-seeks-end-to-hiv-specific-criminal-laws|accessdate=July 22, 2014|work=The Iowa Independent|date=September 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809165410/http://iowaindependent.com/44113/new-group-seeks-end-to-hiv-specific-criminal-laws|archivedate=August 9, 2014|df=}}</ref> In November the Project released a 293-page manual detailing HIV-specific laws and prosecutions in the 50 states, District of Columbia, U.S. Territories, Federal government, and the U.S. military.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ending and Defending Against HIV Criminalization: State and Federal Laws and Prosecutions, Vol.1, First Edition |url=http://www.hivlawandpolicy.org/resources/view/564 |work=The Resource Bank |publisher=Center for HIV Law and Policy |date=Fall 2010 |author=René Bennett-Carlson, |accessdate=December 6, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827115736/http://www.hivlawandpolicy.org/resources/view/564 |archivedate=August 27, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
On March 15, 2014, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) along with the [[Centers for Disease Control]] published a study of HIV-specific state laws called "Prevalence and Public Health Implications of State Laws that Criminalize Potential HIV Exposure in the United States".<ref>[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10461-014-0724-0 "Prevalence and Public Health Implications of State Laws that Criminalize Potential HIV Exposure in the United States", ''AIDS and Behavior'', June 2014, Volume 18, Issue 6, pp 997-1006]., accessed July 21, 2014</ref>
On July 15, 2014, the DOJ released a paper called "Best Practices Guide to Reform HIV-Specific Criminal Laws to Align with Scientifically-Supported Factors", designed to guide states in updating their statutes to "reflect contemporary understanding of HIV transmission routes and associated benefits of treatment" and to establish policies that "do not place unnecessary burdens on individuals living with HIV/AIDS".<ref>U.S. Department of Justice: [http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2014/July/14-crt-739.html "Justice Department Releases Best Practices Guide to Reform HIV-Specific Criminal Laws to Align with Scientifically-Supported Factors", July 15, 2014], accessed July 21, 2014</ref>
===Proposed federal legislation=== REPEAL HIV Discrimination Act was the abbreviated name of the 'Repeal Existing Policies that Encourage and Allow Legal HIV Discrimination Act' (H.R. 3053), also called the REPEAL Act, proposed legislation that was introduced in the U.S. Congress on September 23, 2011, by Rep. [[Barbara Lee]] (D-CA).<ref name=hr3053>[http://beta.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/house-bill/3053?q=hr3053 H.R.3053 - REPEAL Act], retrieved December 6, 2012</ref> It called for review of all federal and state laws, policies, and regulations regarding the criminal prosecution of individuals for HIV-related offenses. It was the first piece of federal legislation to address HIV criminalization and provided incentives for states to reconsider laws and practices that target people with HIV for consensual sexual activity and conduct that poses no risk of HIV transmission.<ref>{{cite web|title=Why Federal Legislation Matters: The REPEAL HIV Discrimination Act, 26 September 2011|url=http://www.hivlawandpolicy.org/posts/view/113|publisher=Center for HIV Law and Policy|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> The bill had 41 cosponsors and was referred in September/October 2011 to three subcommittees, where it died.<ref name=hr3053/>
Barbara Lee re-introduced the REPEAL HIV Discrimination Act 2013 as H.R. 1843 in May 2013 with 42 cosponsors, and it again died in three subcommittees.<ref name=hr1843>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Barbara|title=H.R.1843 - REPEAL HIV Discrimination Act of 2013|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/1843|work=Congress.gov|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=1 May 2014|date=7 May 2013}}</ref> Senator [[Chris Coons]] introduced the legislation as S.1790 on December 10, 2013, and it did not make it out of the Judiciary Committee.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roberts|first=Dan |title=New bill seeks to repeal outdated state HIV discrimination laws|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/10/us-house-hiv-bill-discrimination|accessdate=December 12, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=December 10, 2013}}</ref>
===Immigration=== In 2012, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) used the conviction of Jose Luis Ramirez, an HIV-positive immigrant, of solicitation for oral sex as an argument for his deportation, calling it a "particularly serious crime". An immigration judge ordered his deportation, but the DHS withdrew its argument and the Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA) reversed the deportation order on May 31, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Immigration Court rules in favor of HIV-positive man facing deportation |url=http://sdgln.com/news/2013/06/05/immigration-court-rules-for-hiv-positive-man-facing-deportation|accessdate=June 5, 2013 |newspaper=San Diego Gay & Lesbian News|date=June 5, 2013}}</ref>
==State law and policy==
===Statutes=== As of 2010 "at least 32 states [had] HIV-specific laws that criminalize behavior by people living with HIV." The ACLU has listed states, their statutes, relevant behaviors (spitting, blood donation etc.), and classification of crime as felony or misdemeanor and punishment in a table.<ref name=aclu>{{cite web|title=Criminal statutes on HIV transmission|url=https://www.aclu.org/lgbt-rights_hiv-aids/state-criminal-statutes-hiv-transmission|work=Lesbian and Gay Rights Project|publisher=ACLU|pages=13|format=pdf 123.67 KB|date=June 4, 2008}}</ref>
The following states have laws that prosecute individuals for criminal exposure of HIV: [[Alabama]], [[Alaska]], [[Arkansas]], [[California]], [[Colorado]], [[Delaware]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2010/title-16/chapter-5/article-4/16-5-60/ |title=§ 16-5-60 - Reckless conduct causing harm to or endangering the bodily safety of another; conduct by HIV infected persons; assault by HIV infected persons or hepatitis infected persons :: 2010 Georgia Code :: US Codes and Statutes :: US Law :: Justia |work=law.justia.com/ |accessdate=May 24, 2015}}</ref> [[Idaho]], [[Illinois]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aidslegal.com/LegalAssist/Criminal_Transmission.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718044240/http://www.aidslegal.com/LegalAssist/Criminal_Transmission.pdf |archivedate=2012-07-18 |df= }}</ref> [[Indiana]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gov/legislative/ic/code/title35/ar42/ch1.html |title=Indiana Code 35-42-1 |publisher=In.gov |date=July 1, 1989 |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gov/legislative/ic/code/title35/ar42/ch2.html |title=Indiana Code 35-42-2 |publisher=In.gov |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref> [[Iowa]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.ia.us/IACODE/2003SUPPLEMENT/709C/1.html|title=Iowa Code 2003SUPPLEMENT: Section 709C.1|accessdate=July 18, 2010}}</ref> [[Kansas]], [[Kentucky]], [[Louisiana]], [[Maryland]], [[Michigan]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(fkfegu45tnftpg3kpfjdkhe3))/mileg.aspx?page=GetObject&objectname=mcl-333-5210 |title=Michigan Legislature – Section 333.5210 |publisher=Legislature.mi.gov |date=March 30, 1989 |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref> [[Minnesota]], [[Mississippi]], [[Missouri]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moga.mo.gov/statutes/c100-199/1910000677.htm |title=Section 191-677 Prohibited acts, criminal penalties |publisher=Moga.mo.gov |date=August 28, 2010 |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref> [[Montana]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.opi.mt.gov/bills/mca/50/18/50-18-112.htm |title=50-18-112. Infected person not to expose another to sexually transmitted disease |publisher=Data.opi.mt.gov |accessdate=October 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003130742/http://data.opi.mt.gov/bills/mca/50/18/50-18-112.htm |archivedate=October 3, 2011 |df= }}</ref> [[Nevada]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]],<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/25/nyregion/wave-of-laws-aimed-at-people-with-hiv.html?pagewanted=1 | work=The New York Times | title=Wave of Laws Aimed at People With H.I.V | first=Lynda | last=Richardson | date=September 25, 1998}}</ref> [[North Carolina]],<ref name="Statehealthfacts.org">{{Cite news|url=http://www.statehealthfacts.org/comparetable.jsp?ind=569&cat=11|title=Criminal Statutes on HIV Transmission, 2008|publisher=Statehealthfacts.org|accessdate=July 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526051214/http://www.statehealthfacts.org/comparetable.jsp?cat=11&ind=569|archivedate=May 26, 2010|df=}}</ref> [[North Dakota]], [[Ohio]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2927.13 |title=Lawriter – ORC – 2927.13 Selling or donating contaminated blood |publisher=Codes.ohio.gov |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref> [[Oklahoma]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[South Carolina]], [[South Dakota]], [[Tennessee]], [[Texas]], [[Utah]], [[Virginia]], and [[Washington (state)|Washington]].<ref name="Statehealthfacts.org"/><ref name="Avert.org">{{Cite news|url=http://www.avert.org/criminal-transmission.htm|title=Criminal Transmission of HIV|publisher=Avert.org|accessdate=July 18, 2010}}</ref>
Minnesota has a statute that criminalizes the transmission of certain communicable diseases including HIV. Under that statute, Daniel James Rick, despite having informed his sexual partner of his HIV status, was charged with attempted first-degree assault with great bodily harm. His conviction in the trial court was overturned on appeal, and the Supreme Court of Minnesota on August 21, 2013, agreed that the prosecutor had misapplied the statute's provision meant to address the transmission of a communicable disease in non-sexual contexts, such as sperm or organ donations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Appeals Court Reverses Conviction In HIV Case|url=http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2012/09/24/appeals-court-reverses-conviction-in-hiv-case/ |accessdate=August 21, 2013|newspaper=CBS Minnesota|date=September 24, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Minn. Supreme Court Sides With HIV-Positive Man |url=http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2013/08/21/minn-supreme-court-sides-with-hiv-positive-man/ |accessdate=August 21, 2013|newspaper=CBS Minnesota|date=August 21, 2013}}</ref>
Iowa Code 709c was one of the most severe criminal transmission of HIV law in the country until 1 May 2014. For 16 years it allowed anyone with HIV exposing another person without disclosing his or her positive status, whether infection occurred or not, to be convicted of a class B felony, i.e. up to 25 years in prison and mandated registration as a sex offender.<ref name=code709>{{cite web|title=Iowa Code 709C, criminal transmission of HIV|url=https://coolice.legis.iowa.gov/Cool-ICE/default.asp?category=billinfo&service=IowaCode&ga=83&input=709C7|publisher=Iowa Legislature|accessdate=24 April 2014}}</ref> It has been called "draconian".<ref name=ICPC /> According to the Iowa Department of Public Health, Iowa ranks second in prosecutions behind Tennessee of persons with HIV, despite having a relatively small number of persons living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=IDPH>{{cite web|title=Discussion of Revisions to Iowa Code 709C – Criminal Transmission of HIV|url=http://www.hivlawandpolicy.org/sites/www.hivlawandpolicy.org/files/709C%20Fact%20Sheet%20for%20IDPH.pdf|work=Fact sheet|author=Iowa Department of Public Health|publisher=The Center for HIV Law and Policy|accessdate=25 April 2014|year=2014}}</ref> Efforts to modernize had been underway since at least 2009, led by Community HIV/Hepatitis Advocates of Iowa Network (CHAIN) and 12 other Iowa medical professional, public health, civil rights and stakeholder organizations. Senate File 2297 redefines crimes for transmission of HIV, but also [[hepatitis]], [[tuberculosis]] and [[meningococcal disease]] and introduces a tiered-system of sentencing: Intentional transmission remains a class B felony, but if there is intent and no transmission it is a class D felony, the same as unintentional transmission. It also includes defense in court, if following a treatment regimen and physician’s advice and no longer requires sex offender registration. On 27 February 2014, SF2297 passed the [[Iowa Senate]] by a 48-0 margin<ref name=SF2297>{{cite web|title=Senate File 2297, Contagious or Infectious Disease Transmission Act|url=http://coolice.legis.iowa.gov/Cool-ICE/default.asp?Category=billinfo&Service=Billbook&ga=85&hbill=SF2297|publisher=Iowa Legislature|accessdate=24 April 2014}}</ref> attracting national media attention.<ref name=abc>{{cite news|last=MOHNEY|first=Gillian|title=Controversial HIV Law in Iowa Could Be Changed|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/controversial-hiv-law-iowa-changed/story?id=23071540|accessdate=25 April 2014|newspaper=ABCnews.com|date=27 March 2014}}</ref> The House Judiciary passed an amended version on March 13, 2014 reintroducing "too much of the existing law".<ref name=ICPC>{{cite news|title=Our view: Lawmakers must fix HIV law this session|url=http://www.press-citizen.com/story/opinion/editorials/our-view/2014/04/23/aids-criminal-transmission-hiv/8027691/|accessdate=24 April 2014|newspaper=Iowa City Press Citizen|date=22 April 2014}}</ref> Senate File 2297 remained on the House’s list of unfinished business and was passed after going virtually unmentioned just in time before the legislature's adjournment in the early hours of 1 May 2014.<ref name=dmr>{{cite news|last=Noble|first=Jason|title=Iowa Legislature rewrites 'draconian' HIV transmission bill|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/iowa-politics/2014/05/01/hiv-transmission-law-rewritten/8550737/|accessdate=1 May 2014|newspaper=Des Moines Register|date=1 May 2014}}</ref>
===Prosecutions=== Prosecutions at the state level have included: *[[Thomas Guerra]], who became the first person in the state of [[California]] to be convicted for intentionally infecting another individual with [[HIV]]. In court, prosecutors presented 11,000 text messages and 36 audio clips to support their case against Guerra. Since then, Guerra has been accused of intentionally exposing dozens of other men to the HIV.<ref name="washingtonpost_travesty">{{cite web|author=Michael E. Miller |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/05/05/man-who-knowingly-spread-hiv-sentenced-to-six-months-judge-calls-it-a-travesty/ |title=Man who knowingly spread HIV sentenced to six months. Judge calls it a 'travesty.' |publisher=Washington Post |date=2015-05-05 |accessdate=2015-05-07}}</ref><ref name="cbs8_plea">{{cite web|author=Marcella Lee |url=http://www.cbs8.com/story/28320968/man-pleads-no-contest-to-willfully-spreading-hiv |title=Man pleads no contest to willfully spreading HIV |publisher=CBS8-San Diego |date=2015-03-09 |accessdate=2015-05-07}}</ref><ref name="logo">{{cite web|author=Matthew Tharrett |url=http://www.newnownext.com/man-who-purposefully-infected-his-boyfriend-with-hiv-gets-six-months-in-prison/05/2015 |title=Man Who Purposefully Infected His Boyfriend With HIV Gets Six Months In Prison |publisher=Logo |date=2015-05-05 |accessdate=2015-05-06}}</ref> *Nick Rhoades, an HIV-positive man living in Iowa, who had an undetectable viral load, was sentenced to 25 years after a single sexual encounter during which he used a condom but did not disclose his HIV status (''Rhoades v. State of Iowa'').<ref>{{cite news |last=Young |first=Saundra |title=Imprisoned over HIV: One man's story|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/02/health/criminalizing-hiv/index.html |accessdate=December 6, 2012 |newspaper=CNN Health|date=November 9, 2012}}</ref> *An HIV-positive man was sentenced to 10 years in prison for aggravated assault after biting a police officer. His saliva was considered to be the dangerous instrument for the purpose of the "aggravated" portion of the charge (''People v. Plunkett'', New York Court of Appeals).<ref>{{cite news|title=Court of Appeals — Aggravated Assault of a Police Officer: People v. Plunkett|url=http://nydailyrecord.com/blog/2012/06/28/court-of-appeals-aggravated-assault-of-a-police-officer-people-v-plunkett/|accessdate=December 6, 2012|newspaper=The Daily Record|date=June 28, 2012}}</ref> *A man in Oregon was convicted of ten counts of attempted murder and ten counts of attempted assault based on allegations that he engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse without disclosing his medical condition (''State of Oregon v. Hinkhouse'').<ref>{{cite book|last=Shevory|first=Thomas|title=Notorious H.I.V.: The Media Spectacle of Nushawn Williams|year=2004|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|location=Minneapolis|pages=146–7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=76nLLlg4rsEC&pg=PT169&}}</ref> *An HIV-positive 25-year-old serving in the U.S. Army, was ordered in November 2006 to inform any sexual partner of his HIV status. After he had sex with a 17-year-old male who became infected, he was charged in June 2007 with "[[crimes against nature]], assault and assault with a deadly weapon".<ref>{{cite news|last=St. Clair|first=Mark|title=Army: No link found between HIV-positive soldier and unit deployed to Afghanistan|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/army-no-link-found-between-hiv-positive-soldier-and-unit-deployed-to-afghanistan-1.66930|accessdate=December 30, 2012|newspaper=Stars and Stripes|date=July 26, 2007}}</ref> He pleaded guilty in November to 3 counts of "aggravated assault by means likely to cause grievous bodily harm or death" and other charges. He was sentenced to serve 40 months in [[military prison]], a reduction in rank to private, and a dishonorable discharge.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mims|first=Bryan|title=Soldier Pleads Guilty to Passing HIV Infection |url=http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/1992178/|accessdate=December 30, 2012|newspaper=WRAL|date=November 1, 2007}}</ref> *An HIV-positive U.S. Navy officer and Catholic priest pleaded guilty in December 2007 to several crimes committed against U.S. Naval Academy midshipmen he was counseling, including forcible [[Sodomy law in the United States|sodomy]] and [[indecent assault]]. Charges of assault were changed to aggravated assault because of his HIV status.<ref>{{cite news|last=Melloy|first=Kilian|title=Navy Chaplain Faces Court Martial for Gay Sexual Assaults|url=http://www.edgeboston.com/index.php?ch=news&sc=glbt&sc3=&id=53360 |accessdate=December 30, 2012|newspaper=EDGE|date=December 6, 2007}}</ref>
[[Center for hiv law and policy|The Center for HIV Law and Policy]] has documented 168 cases of prosecution between January 2008 and June 2013.<ref>{{cite web |title=Prosecutions for HIV Exposure in the United States, 2008–2013|url=http://www.hivlawandpolicy.org/resources/view/456 |work=The Center for HIV Law & Policy, Positive Justice Project|accessdate=August 13, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Criminal transmission of HIV]] *[[Presidential Advisory Council on HIV/AIDS]] *[[Nushawn Williams]], a man who was prosecuted for criminal transmission of HIV *[[Prison rape in the United States#Sexually transmitted diseases]] *[[Infectious diseases within American prisons#HIV/AIDS]] *[[Center for hiv law and policy|The Center for HIV Law and Policy]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.hivlawandpolicy.org/public/initiatives/positivejusticeproject Positive Justice Project] *[http://projects.propublica.org/tables/penalties State-by-State: HIV Laws]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Criminal Transmission Of Hiv In The United States}} [[Category:Criminal transmission of HIV]] [[Category:United States criminal law]] [[Category:Health policy in the United States]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS in the United States]]

revision.comment: updated description of Dubai Design Week
revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | name = | logo = | image = Dubai_Design_Week_Logo.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | genre = Design Festival | frequency = Annually | location = [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | first = 2015 | founder_name = | prev = November 2017 | next = 12-17 November 2018 | participants = | attendance =60,000 in 2017 | area = [[Dubai]] | budget = | patron =Sheikha Latifa bint Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum | organised = Art Dubai Group, supported by d3 and Dubai Culture | people = | member = | website = http://www.dubaidesignweek.ae/ | footnotes = }}
'''Dubai Design Week''' is an annual event held to celebrate and promote design and creativity in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. The first Dubai Design Week took place in 2015, and is held every November at venues across the city, with the hub location of [[Dubai Design District]] .<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thenational.ae/arts-lifestyle/art/dubai-design-week-to-boost-uaes-design-industry| title = Dubai Design Week to boost UAE’s design industry| date = September 28, 2015| access-date = November 2, 2016| language = en| trans-title = }}</ref> With a programme of over 200 free-to-attend exhibitions, talks, workshops, the 2017 festival attracted over 60,000 visitors and as such It is considered the largest creative festival in the Middle East.
Providing a meeting point for the global design community, Dubai Design Week represents the region's design talent while engaging with the growing design and creative community in Dubai and the UAE. More information is available on the [http://www.dubaidesignweek.ae/ Dubai Design Week Website] and social media channels including [https://www.instagram.com/Dubaidesignweek/ Instagram] and [https://www.facebook.com/dubaidesignweek?fref=ts Facebook].e
The next edition of Dubai Design Week takes place 12-17 November 2018.
==Overview== Dubai Design Week is run by the Art Dubai Group and was founded under the patronage of [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum#Children|Sheikha Latifa bint Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]], in association with [[Dubai Design District]]. It is supported by [http://www.audi-me.com/me/web/meen.html Audi Middle East] and has [[Dubai Culture and Arts Authority]] as a strategic partner and is one of a series of initiatives aimed at developing design and innovation in Dubai by fostering a creative environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dubaidesignweek.ae/news/2015/october/her-highness-sheikha-latifa-bint-mohammed-inaugurates-dubai-design-week/|title=HER HIGHNESS SHEIKHA LATIFA BINT MOHAMMED INAUGURATES DUBAI DESIGN WEEK|date=October 27, 2015|language=en|trans-title=|access-date=November 3, 2016}}</ref>
The six-day event showcases a wide variety of design skills and disciplines including: [[architecture]], [[Product design|product]] and [[Furniture Design|furniture design]], [[interior design]], [[jewelry]], [[industrial design]], [[service design]], technology [[culture]], [[art]], and more.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://whatson.ae/dubai/2016/10/ultimate-guide-dubai-design-week-2016/| title = Your ultimate guide to Dubai Design Week 2016| date = October 24, 2016 | access-date = November 3, 2016| language = en| trans-title = }}</ref> and the programme includes content from over 100 partner organisations.
Dubai Design District (d3) provides the main hub for Dubai Design Week, staging activity and events for a wide variety of visitors; from design and architecture professionals through to a dedicated children's programme during the festival's weekend.
===Downtown Design=== Downtown Design is the only trade show in the [[Middle East]] for design professionals, showcasing a variety of commercial designs from various industries. It was originally launched prior to the Dubai Design Week but was then added as one of the events during the weekly event.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.downtowndesign.com/about/about-downtown-design/| title = ABOUT DOWNTOWN DESIGN| access-date = November 3, 2016| language = en| trans-title = }}</ref>
===Global Grad Show=== The Global Grad Show is an event held at the Dubai Design Week every year. It is a showcase of projects from students in top design [[universities]] around the world, such as the [[Royal College of Arts]], [[Keio University]] and [[KAIST]]. The projects are curated based on unique and interesting experiences that range from ultra-technical to incredibly simple.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://observer.com/2016/11/12-game-changing-innovations-we-found-at-dubai-design-week/| title = 12 Game Changing Innovations We Found at Dubai Design Week| date = November 2, 2016| access-date = November 3, 2016| language = en| trans-title = }}</ref>
In 2016, the Global Grad Show invited 145 projects from 50 universities in 30 countries, almost tripling the amount of projects from its inaugural year, making it the largest global design showcase for students.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.designboom.com/design/2016-dubai-design-week-student-global-grad-show-10-07-2016/| title = 2016 dubai design week gathers student innovators at global grad show| date = October 7, 2016| access-date = November 2, 2016| language = en| trans-title = }}</ref>
===Abwab=== Abwab, the word for 'doors' in [[Arabic]], is a showcase of work from countries in the MENASA region. Different countries are selected every year and designers from that region showcase their work in interactive pavilions. [[Jordan]], [[Kuwait]], [[Pakistan]], [[Saudi Arabia]], and the [[UAE]] were selected in 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dubaidesignweek.ae/2015-archive/projects-2015/abwab/| title = ABWAB| date =| access-date = November 10, 2016| language = en| trans-title = }}</ref> The 2016 edition featured [[Algeria]], [[India]], [[Iraq]], [[Bahrain]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], and the [[UAE]].<ref name="Expansion Plans">{{cite web|url=http://saudigazette.com.sa/life/dubai-design-week-reveals-expansion-growth-plans/|title=Dubai Design Week reveals expansion, growth plans|date=November 5, 2016|language=en|trans-title=|access-date=November 8, 2016}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.dubaidesignweek.ae/ Dubai Design Week Official Site] * [http://www.downtowndesign.com/ Downtown Design Official Site] * [http://www.globalgradshow.com/ Global Grad Show Official Site]

The '''Döbbelinsches Theater''' or '''Döbbelin Theater''', was a theater in Berlin, active between 1764 to 1799. It was the first permanent German language theater in Berlin. It was founded by [[Karl Schuch]] and named after its director, [[Karl Theophil Döbbelin]]. Prior to its foundation, Berlin had an opera house (founded in 1742) which only employed Italian artists, and travelling theater troupes often visited the city, but the Döbbeling theater was the first permanent theater for a permanent German language stage company.
==References== {{reflist}} * Dagmar Claus: Einer, der den Hanswurst vertrieb. Carl Theophil Doebbelin (1727–1793). In: Berlinische Monatsschrift 2/1997 beim Luisenstädtischen Bildungsverein, S. 68ff

The '''Eifel Music Festival''' ({{lang-de|Eifeler Musikfest}}) is a church music festival that has been held every year since 1946 on the weekend after [[Pentecost]] at [[Steinfeld Abbey]]/[[Eifel]]. This makes it the oldest extant music festival in the Rhineland. Today, the county of [[Euskirchen (district)|Euskirchen]] is the responsible body in cooperation with the support association of Steinfeld Abbey.
== Concept == In keeping with the spirit of the monastic venue, the Eifel Music Festival is a Catholic church music festival. The festival's [[Solemn Mass|High Mass]] (''Festhochamt'') cultivates the tradition of the ''[[missa solemnis]]'', the [[church service]] accompanied ceremonially by [[Choir (music)|choir]] and [[orchestra]]. The highlight of the music festival is an [[Oratorium|oratorial concert]] on Sunday afternoon, at which great works of [[church music]] from [[Claudio Monteverdi|Monteverdi]] to [[Anton Bruckner|Bruckner]] are performed. Since the late 1950s, in addition to the church music concerts, there has been a concert of [[chamber music]] on Saturday evening with a "secular" programme is staged at various locations within the great monastery complex. From time to time, the festival programme is supplemented by an [[organ music|organ concert]] with well-known [[organist]]s playing Steinfeld's Balthasar König Organ on the Sunday afternoon.
== Artists == Until 1963, the artistic direction was in the hands of Aachen Cathedral's director of music and founder, Professor Theodor Bernhard Rehmann (1895-1963). Conductors have included [[Wolfgang Sawallisch]], Romanus Hubertus, Wolfgang Trommer and Hans Walter Kämpfel.
== History == The Eifel Music Festival was inaugurated in 1946 on the initiative of the Bishop of Aachen [[Johannes Joseph van der Velden]] and his Director of Music, Theodor Bernhard Rehmann. The idea was to bring "music culture" to the impoverished and war-damaged Eifel region. After a few years, the Eifel Music Festival developed into a popular folk festival in the region. As well as the festival's [[Solemn Mass|high mass]] and organ concert there was an open-air performance in the monastery courtyard; a symphony concert with the [[Aachen Symphony Orchestra]] and works mainly by [[Anton Bruckner|Bruckner]] and [[Beethoven]].
The [[Aachen Cathedral Choir]] also maintains the tradition of organizing the high mass at the Eifel Music Festival musically under [[Prelate]] Dr. Rudolf Pohl, the successor to Rehmann in the post of conductor of the Cathedral Orchestra. The afternoon oratorio concert was for many years in the hands of [[Bonn]]'s [[Bach Choir, Bonn|Bach Choir]], and its conductor Professor Gustav Classens. In the seventies and eighties of the 20th century, other renowned concert choirs from Cologne, Mainz and Düsseldorf also performed at the Eifel Music Festival.
== Literature == * Hans-Peter Göttgens: ''Das Eifeler Musikfest''. In: Musikwissenschaftliches Institut der University of Cologne (publ.): ''Mitteilungen der Arbeitsgemeinschaft für rheinische Musikgeschichte e.V. No. 89'', Cologne, 2007. * Alfred Beaujean: ''25 Jahre Eifeler Musikfest''. In: Kreis Schleiden (publ.): ''Heimatjahrbuch 1970''. Bonn, 1969.
