revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox Instrument |name=Vuvuzela |image=Vuvuzela red.jpg |image_capt = A modern plastic Vuvuzela |background=brass |classification= Brass{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} * Wind * [[Brass instrument|Brass]]{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} * [[Aerophone]] |hornbostel_sachs=423.121.22 |hornbostel_sachs_desc=Tubular end-blown trumpet with mouthpiece |range=Varies by instrument, typically around B♭ |related=[[Kuduzela|Kudu]], [[bugle]] |article= }} [[File:Vuvuzela-DD.jpg|thumb|260px|A black and yellow striped vuvuzela]] {{listen |filename=Vuvuzela single note.ogg |image=[[File:Vuvuzelas1.svg|40px]] |title=Vuvuzela note |description=A standard short {{convert|58|cm|ft|abbr=on}} vuvuzela plays a single B{{music|flat}} note.}}
The '''vuvuzela''' {{IPAc-en|v|uː|v|uː|ˈ|z|ɛ|l|ə}}, also known as '''lepatata''' (its [[Tswana language|Tswana]] name),{{cn|date=June 2018}} is a [[plastic]] [[Horn (acoustic)|horn]], about {{convert|65|cm|ft|0}} long, which produces a loud monotone note, typically around [[B♭ (musical note)|B{{music|flat}}]] [[Scientific pitch notation|3]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/10312794.stm|title=10 things about the vuvuzela |work=BBC News|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|date=June 15, 2010}}</ref> (the B{{music|flat}} below [[middle C]]).<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.qmul.ac.uk/media/news/items/se/30760.html|title=Trumping the trumpets: how audio engineering helps tone down vuvuzela disruption|date=June 18, 2010|publisher=Queen Mary College University of London}}</ref> Some models are made in two parts to facilitate storage, and this design also allows pitch variation. Many types of vuvuzela, made by several manufacturers, may produce various intensity and frequency outputs.<ref name="Journal1">{{Cite journal|format=PDF|title=Vuvuzela sound measurements|url=http://www.samj.org.za/index.php/samj/article/viewFile/4098/2735|journal=South African Medical Journal|volume=100|issue=4|date=April 2010|page=192|first1=De Wet|last1=Swanepoel|first2=James W|last2=Hall III|first3=Dirk|last3=Koekemoer|location=Cape Town, South Africa|pmid=20459951}}</ref> The intensity of these outputs depends on the blowing technique and pressure exerted.<ref name="Journal1"/>
Traditionally made and inspired from a [[kudu]] horn, the vuvuzela was used to summon distant villagers to attend community gatherings.<ref name="Journal2"/>{{Dubious|Disputed information|date=July 2010}} The vuvuzela is commonly used at [[association football|football]] matches in [[South Africa]],<ref name=fifa> {{cite web|url= https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/destination/southafricafromatoz/letter=v/index.html|title=V is for Vuvuzela|work=Fédération Internationale de Football Association|accessdate=September 9, 2008}}</ref> and it has become a symbol of South African football as the stadiums are filled with its sound.<ref name="Journal2">{{Cite journal|format=PDF|title=Vuvuzela – good for your team, bad for your ears|url=http://www.scielo.org.za/pdf/samj/v100n2/v100n2a15.pdf|journal=South African Medical Journal|volume=100|issue=4|date=February 2010|pages=99–100|first1=De Wet|last1=Swanepoel|first2=James W|last2=Hall III|first3=Dirk|last3=Koekemoer|location=Cape Town, South Africa|pmid=20459912}}</ref> The intensity of the sound caught the attention of the global football community during the [[2009 FIFA Confederations Cup]] in anticipation of South Africa hosting the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name="Journal2"/>
The vuvuzela has been the subject of controversy when used by spectators at football matches. Its high sound pressure levels at close range can lead to permanent [[hearing loss]] for unprotected ears after exposure,<ref name="Journal3">{{Cite journal|url= http://www.scielo.org.za/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0256-95742010000400024&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en |journal=South African Medical Journal|title=Football match spectator sound exposure and effect on hearing: A pretest-post-test study |first1=D Wet|last1=Swanepoel|first2=James W|last2=Hall III|date=April 2010|volume=100 |issue=4|location=Cape Town, South Africa|pmid= 20459971|pages= 239–42}}</ref> with a [[Sound intensity level|sound level]] of 120 [[decibel|dB(A)]] (the threshold of pain) at {{convert|1|m|ft}} from the device opening.<ref name="Journal2"/>
==Origin== [[File:Shona witch doctor (Zimbabwe).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Kudu vuvuzela blown by a [[N'anga]] in Zimbabwe in 1989.]] [[File:The Dinner Horn (Blowing the Horn at Seaside), by Winslow Homer, 1870.png|left|thumb|The Dinner Horn (Blowing the Horn at Seaside), by [[Winslow Homer]], 1870.]] Plastic [[aerophones]], like ''corneta'' and similar devices, have been used in [[Brazil]] and other Latin American countries since the 1960s.
These plastic horns have been marketed and available in the United States as "Stadium Horns" since the mid-1960s.<ref>{{Cite episode | title = 8th Inning – A Whole New Ballgame | episodelink = | url = | series = Baseball | serieslink = Baseball (TV series) | credits = Ken Burns | network = PBS | station = | city = | airdate = September 27, 1994 | began = | ended = | season = 1 | seriesno = | number = | minutes = 82 | transcript = | transcripturl = | quote = at 1:22:12, crowd shot of [[Fenway Park]]. In the upper left corner of the frame, two mass-produced type plastic Stadium Horns/Vuvuzelas are clearly visible. }}</ref> Similar horns have been in existence for much longer. An instrument that looks like a vuvuzela appears in [[Winslow Homer|Winslow Homer's]] 1870 woodcut "The Dinner Horn".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/brooklynmuseum-o2502-the-dinner-horn|publisher=Brooklyn Museum of Art|title=The Dinner Horn}}</ref>
The origin of the device is disputed. The term ''vuvuzela'' was first used in South Africa from the [[Zulu language]] or [[Nguni languages|Nguni]] dialect meaning to make a ''vuvu'' sound (directly translated: vuvu-ing).{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Controversies over the invention arose in early 2010. South African [[Kaizer Chiefs F.C.|Kaizer Chiefs]] fan Freddie "Saddam" <!--NOT A SPELLING ERROR-->Maake<!--NOT A SPELLING ERROR--> claimed the invention of the vuvuzela by fabricating an aluminium version in 1965 from a bicycle horn and has photographic evidence of himself holding the aluminium vuvuzela in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s.<ref name="Freddie Saddam Maake">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-01-08-vuvuzela-creator-blown-off|work=Mail & Guardian |title=Vuvuzela creator blown off?|first=Phathisani|last=Moyo|date=January 8, 2010|location=South Africa}}</ref> He also claimed to have coined ''vuvuzela'' from the Zulu language for "welcome", "unite" and "celebration".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/jul/10/i-invented-the-vuvuzela |title=Experience: I invented the vuvuzela|first=Freddie|last=Maake|date=July 10, 2010|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London}}</ref> Plastics factory Masincedane Sport popularised the ubiquitous plastic vuvuzela commonly heard at South African football games in 2002,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://g.sports.yahoo.com/soccer/world-cup/news/vuvuzela-inventor-cashes-in-on-success-at-wcup--fbintl_ap-wcup-vuvuzela.html|title=Vuvuzela innovator cashes in on success at WCup|first=Raf|last=Casert|date=June 18, 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Yahoo! Inc|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100622001244/http://g.sports.yahoo.com/soccer/world-cup/news/vuvuzela-inventor-cashes-in-on-success-at-wcup--fbintl_ap-wcup-vuvuzela.html|archivedate=June 22, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and the [[Nazareth Baptist Church]] claimed the vuvuzela belonged to their church.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8458829.stm|title=Unholy row over World Cup trumpet|accessdate=January 16, 2010 |last=Fisher |first=Jonah |date=January 16, 2010 |work=BBC News|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> {{clear}}
==International tournaments== [[File:Vuvuzelas 1.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A 2010 [[FIFA World Cup]] crowd blowing vuvuzelas]] The world association football governing body, [[FIFA]], proposed banning vuvuzelas from stadiums, as they were seen as potential weapons for [[Football hooliganism|hooligans]] and could be used in [[ambush marketing]]. Columnist Jon Qwelane described the device as "an instrument from hell".<ref name="jqInstrumentFromHell">{{Cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/Columnists/Archive/JonQwelane/Ban-the-vuvuzela-20050207|title=Ban the vuvuzela|last=Qwelane|first=Jon|work=News24|publisher=24.com|date=February 7, 2005|location=South Africa}}</ref> South African football authorities argued that the vuvuzela was part of the South African football experience.<ref> {{Cite news|last=Makhaye |first=Chris |date=July 13, 2008|title=Blasts of joy as vuvuzelas unbanned|publisher=IOL|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=6&click_id=2871&art_id=vn20080713120228203C272609}}</ref> The Spanish midfielder [[Xabi Alonso]] said, "Those trumpets? That noise I don't like ... FIFA must ban those things ... it is not nice to have a noise like that".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.capeargus.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=5041732|title=Ban the noisy vuvuzela, says Alonso|date=June 18, 2009|work=Cape Argus|publisher= Cape Argus & Independent Online}}</ref> Dutch coach [[Bert van Marwijk]] remarked, "... it was annoying ... in the stadiums you get used to it but it is still unpleasant".<ref name="ESPN Soccernet">{{Cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=656178&sec=global&cc=5901 |title=Dutch coach joins chorus to ban vuvuzela|work=ESPNsoccernet|publisher=Walt Disney Internet Group|agency=Reuters|date=June 20, 2009 |accessdate=June 20, 2009}}</ref>
Commentator Farayi Mungazi said, "Banning the vuvuzela would take away the distinctiveness of a South African World Cup ... absolutely essential for an authentic South African footballing experience".<ref name="BBC2">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8108691.stm|title=In defence of the vuvuzela|work=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|date=June 19, 2009|last=Mungazi|first=Farayi|accessdate=June 14, 2010}}</ref> FIFA President [[Sepp Blatter]] responded, "we should not try to Europeanise an African World Cup ... that is what African and South Africa football is all about – noise, excitement, dancing, shouting and enjoyment".<ref name="BBC2"/><ref name="ESPN Soccernet" /> Despite the criticisms, FIFA agreed to permit their use in stadiums during the 2009 FIFA Confederations Cup and 2010 FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Fifa gives Vuvuzelas thumbs up|date=July 11, 2008|url=http://www.news24.com/xArchive/Sport/SWC2010/Fifa-gives-Vuvuzelas-thumbs-up-20080711|agency=South African Press Association|work=News24|publisher=24.com|location=South Africa}}</ref> The South African football authority argued that during FIFA World Cup 2010, vuvuzelas achieved great popularity, though TV spectators suffered a lot due to vuvuzela noise pollution.<ref name="ESPN Soccernet"/> {{clear}}
===2010 FIFA World Cup===
====Marketing====
[[Hyundai]] constructed the world's largest working vuvuzela as part of a marketing campaign for the World Cup. The {{convert|35|m|ft|adj=on}} blue vuvuzela mounted on the [[Foreshore Freeway Bridge]], [[Cape Town]] was intended to be used at the beginning of each match; however, it had not yet sounded a note during the World Cup as its volume was a cause of concern to city authorities.<ref name="SilentGiant">{{Cite news|last=Hudson|first=Alexandra|title=Giant vuvuzela waits for council go-ahead to toot|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idAFJOE65H0MC20100618|accessdate=June 19, 2010|agency=Reuters Africa|date=June 18, 2010|publisher=Thomson Reuters Corporate}}</ref>
====Reception==== {{listen |filename=2010-06-14_VOA_News_report_-_Noisy_Vuvuzelas_Cause_Concern_at_World_Cup.ogg |title=Noisy Vuvuzelas cause concern |image=[[File:Vuvuzelas1.svg|40px]] |description=[[Voice of America]] report on the impact of vuvuzelas at the 2010 FIFA World Cup.}} Its ubiquity led to many suggestions for limiting its use, muffling its sound, and even an outright ban.<ref>{{cite web|title=Noisy Vuvuzelas Cause Concern at World Cup|last=Schy|first=Steve|location=Washington, DC, United States of America|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Noisy-Vuvuzelas-Cause-Concern-at-World-Cup-96305284.html|work=Voice of America|publisher=Federal Government of the United States|accessdate=June 18, 2010|date=June 14, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Organizers consider silencing vuvuzelas|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/world-cup/story/_/id/5282269/ce/us/organizers-consider-silencing-vuvuzelas&cc=5901?ver=us|work=ESPNsoccernet|publisher=Walt Disney Internet Group|accessdate=June 14, 2010}}</ref>
Broadcasting organisations experienced difficulties with their presentations. Television and radio audiences often heard only the sound of vuvuzelas.<ref name="BBC1">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10317767.stm|title=BBC receives 545 vuvuzela complaints over World Cup|work=BBC News|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|date=June 15, 2010|accessdate=June 15, 2010}}</ref><ref name="ESPN1">{{Cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/world-cup/story/_/id/5287552/ce/us/bbc-mulls-vuvuzela-free-option-viewers?cc=5901&ver=us|title=Host broadcasters to 'filter' noise|date=June 15, 2010|agency=Associated Press|work=ESPNsoccernet|publisher=Walt Disney Internet Group}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=BBC mulls vuvuzela-free option for irked viewers|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/soccer/news?slug=txwcupvuvuzelasbbc|accessdate=June 17, 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Yahoo! Inc|date=June 15, 2010}}</ref><ref name="nyp1">{{Cite news| title=Buzz off, vuvuzelas! | work=New York Post|publisher=NYP Holdings, Inc| url=http://www.nypost.com/p/sports/more_sports/buzz_off_vuvuzelas_FPa9BYlmlRWJMsF1W65cyJ?CMP=OTC-rss&FEEDNAME= | first=Elio | last=Valenti | date=June 13, 2010 }}</ref> The [[BBC]], [[RTÉ]], [[ESPN]] and [[BSkyB]] have examined the possibility of filtering the ambient noise while maintaining game commentary.<ref name="BBC1"/><ref name="ESPN1"/>
The vuvuzelas raised health and safety concerns. Competitors believed the incessant noise hampered the ability of the players to get their rest, and degraded the quality of team performance.<ref name="bbcponder">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8737455.stm|title=World Cup 2010: Organisers will not ban vuvuzelas|work=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|date=June 13, 2010|accessdate=June 13, 2010}}</ref><ref name="google1">{{Cite news|agency=Agence France-Presse|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ghUbctrzM88GqP_A_qJZppPbhjVw |title=World Cup organiser mulls vuvuzela ban|publisher=Google|date=June 13, 2010|accessdate=June 13, 2010}}</ref> Other critics remarked that vuvuzelas disrupted team communication and players' concentration during matches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/sport/football/article454621.ece |title=It is impossible to communicate, it's like being deaf: Messi|work=The Hindu|agency=Deutsche Presse-Agentur|accessdate=June 13, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/international-justice/bulletin/ronaldo-hits-out-vuvuzelas|title=Ronaldo hits out at vuvuzelas|publisher=Radio Nederland Wereldomroep|agency=Netherlands National News, Agence France-Presse|accessdate=June 13, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617160420/http://www.rnw.nl/international-justice/bulletin/ronaldo-hits-out-vuvuzelas|archive-date=June 17, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Demand for earplugs to protect from hearing loss during the World Cup outstripped supply, with many pharmacies out of stock.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=111728 |title=Worried fans right to seek ear plugs, says Phonak|work=BusinessDay|publisher=BDFM Publishers|last=Chilwane|first=Luphert|date=June 11, 2010|accessdate=June 15, 2010}}</ref> One major vuvuzela manufacturer even began selling its own earplugs to spectators.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sport24.co.za/Soccer/WorldCup/NationalNews/Vuvuzelas-unplugged-for-some-20100611|title=Vuvuzelas unplugged for some|work=Sport24|publisher=24.com|location=South Africa|date=June 11, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722052239/http://www.sport24.co.za/Soccer/WorldCup/NationalNews/Vuvuzelas-unplugged-for-some-20100611|archivedate=July 22, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
====Audio filtration==== [[Band-stop filter|Notch filtering]], an audio filtration technique, is proposed to reduce the vuvuzela sound in broadcasts and increase clarity of commentary audio. The vuvuzela produces notes at a frequency of approximately 235 Hz and its [[overtone|first partial]] at 465 Hz.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Silence Vuvuzela Horns in World Cup Broadcasts|url=http://lifehacker.com/5564085/how-to-silence-vuvuzela-horns-with-an-eq-filter|last=Pash|first=Adam|date=June 15, 2010|publisher=Gawker Media|work=Lifehacker|accessdate=June 17, 2010}}</ref> However, this filtration technique affects the clarity of commentary audio. Proposals of [[adaptive filter]]s by universities and research organisations address this issue by preserving the amplitude and clarity of the commentators' voices and crowd noise.<ref name="qmvuvupr">{{Cite press release | title = Trumping the trumpets: how audio engineering helps tone down vuvuzela disruption | publisher = Queen Mary University of London | date = June 18, 2010 |work=Centre for Digital Music| url = http://www.qmul.ac.uk/media/news/items/se/30760.html | accessdate = June 21, 2010}}</ref><ref name="vuvux">{{cite web|url=http://vuvux.com/ |title=Prosoniq VuvuX|publisher=Prosoniq Products Software GmbH|accessdate=June 21, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stardock.com/labs/devuvuzelator/ |title=The Devuvuzelator|first1=Jeff|last1=Bargmann|last2=University of London|first2=Queen Mary|publisher=Stardock Corporation |accessdate=June 21, 2010}}</ref> Such filtration techniques have been adopted by some cable television providers.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Portuguese cable provider offers vuvuzela muting service for World Cup games|url=http://trueslant.com/marceloballve/2010/06/17/portuguese-cable-provider-offers-vuvuzela-muting-service-for-world-cup-games/|date=June 17, 2010|last=Ballve|first=Marcelo|work=True/Slant}}</ref>
=== 2018 FIFA World Cup ===
The vuvuzelas made a comeback at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia, and have been used mainly by [[Iran national football team|Iranian supporters]].<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/world-cup-2018-morocco-vs-iran-highlights-vuvuzela-goals-five-things-learned-score-a8401226.html]</ref> Much like in 2010, there has been a backlash against the use of vuvuzelas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/vuvuzelas-world-cup-morocco-iran/|title=Vuvuzelas are back at the World Cup and people are fuming|date=June 16, 2018|publisher=inews.co.uk|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://gulfnews.com/sport/football/vuvuzelas-i-hate-them-but-they-are-back-1.2240135|title=Vuvuzelas: I hate them, but they are back|first=Shyam A. Krishna, Opinion|last=Editor|date=June 21, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
==Health effects and regulation==
===Health concerns=== [[File:Vuvuzelas Warning.jpg|thumb|right|Some vuvuzelas carry a safety warning graphic.]] A study in 2010 by Dr Ruth McNerney of the [[London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine]], and colleagues, concluded that the spread of diseases by means of vuvuzelas was possible.<ref name="MiaSnyman">{{Cite news|last=Snyman|first=Mia|title=Study: Vuvuzela could spread colds and flu|publisher=Boston.com|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/soccer/articles/2010/06/10/study_vuvuzela_could_spread_colds_and_flu/|agency=Associated Press |date=June 10, 2010|accessdate=November 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/playbook/2011/05/vuvuzelas-airborne-germs |date=May 24, 2011 |publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired magazine]] |author=Brian Mossop |title=Besides Noise, Vuvuzelas May Spread Airborne Germs}}</ref> McNerney found tiny droplets at the bottom of a vuvuzela that can carry [[flu]] and [[Common cold|cold germs]] that are small enough to stay suspended in the air for hours, and can enter into the airways of a person's lungs. The vuvuzelas can infect others on a greater scale than coughing or shouting.
The vuvuzelas have the potential to cause [[noise-induced hearing loss]].<ref name="Journal1"/><ref name="Journal2"/><ref name="Journal3"/><ref name="MiaSnyman"/> Prof James Hall III, Dr Dirk Koekemoer, De Wet Swanepoel and colleagues at the [[University of Pretoria]] found that vuvuzelas can have a negative effect when a listener's eardrums are exposed to the instrument's high-intensity sound. The vuvuzelas produce an average sound pressure of 113 dB(A) at {{convert|2|m|ft}} from the device opening.<ref name="Journal2"/> The study finds that subjects should not be exposed to more than 15 minutes per day at an intensity of 100 dB(A).<ref name="Journal2"/> The study assumes that if a single vuvuzela emits a sound that is dangerously loud to subjects within a 2-metre radius, and numerous vuvuzelas are typically blown together for the duration of a match, it may put spectators at a significant risk of hearing loss.<ref name="Journal2"/> Hearing loss experts at the U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) recommend that exposure at the 113 dB(A) level not exceed 45 seconds per day.<ref name=NIOSHvuvuzela>{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.cdc.gov/niosh-science-blog/2010/06/17/vuvuzelas/ |title=CDC/NIOSH Science Blog – Vuvuzelas: What's the Buzz? June 2010|work=NIOSH|publisher=cdc.com/niosh|date=June 2010}}</ref> A newer model has a modified mouthpiece that reduces the volume by 20 dB.<ref name=Sport24>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sport24.co.za/Soccer/WorldCup/NationalNews/New-vuvuzelas-turn-down-volume-20100614|title=New vuvuzelas turn down volume|work=Sport24|publisher=24.com|accessdate=June 14, 2010|date=June 14, 2010|location=South Africa|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222134753/http://www.sport24.co.za/Soccer/WorldCup/NationalNews/New-vuvuzelas-turn-down-volume-20100614|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Noise levels and bans=== Concerns about the constant intensities produced by the vuvuzelas during the 2010 FIFA World Cup matches were raised independently by representatives of international football teams, spectators and sports commentators. The noise levels that were demonstrated during the 2010 FIFA World Cup prompted various sporting organisations to ban the vuvuzela at future events and venues, even including future World Cups:
* [[Wembley Stadium]] (as part of an overall ban of noisemakers)<ref name="WembleynBan">{{Cite web |title=Rules & Regulations |work=Wembley Stadium |url=http://www.wembleystadium.com/TheStadium/StadiumGuide/RulesnRegulations|accessdate=June 19, 2013}}</ref> * [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/06/wooomp-fifa-bans-vuvuzelas-from-brazilian-world-cup/372195/|title=Wooomp: FIFA Bans Vuvuzelas from Brazilian World Cup|first=Connor|last=Simpson|date=June 4, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/2018-world-cup/88426/2018-world-cup-roll-up-for-obese-person-tickets|title=2018 World Cup: Roll up for ‘obese person’ tickets|publisher=|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> and [[2022 FIFA World Cup|2022]] [[FIFA World Cup]]s * All sporting events at the [[Cardiff City Stadium|Cardiff City]], [[SWALEC Stadium|SWALEC]], and [[Millennium Stadium]]s<ref>{{Cite news|title=Sports fans in Cardiff spared vuvuzela|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east_wales/10353020.stm|work=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|date=June 18, 2010|accessdate=June 19, 2010}}</ref> * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]<ref name="WimbledonBan">{{Cite news|last=Summers|first=Chris|title=Wimbledon crackdown on vuvuzelas |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/wimbledon/8744027.stm|work=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=June 19, 2010 | date=June 16, 2010}}</ref> * [[Lord's Cricket Ground]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/call-to-ban-vuvuzelas-at-edgbaston-127870|title=Call to ban vuvuzelas at Edgbaston|first=Neil|last=Elkes|date=July 9, 2010|publisher=|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> * [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]]<ref>{{Cite news|title=Vuvu gets big no-no from AFL|last=Doherty|first=Elissa|newspaper=Herald Sun|publisher=News Corporation|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/vuvu-gets-big-no-no-from-afl/story-e6frf9if-1225880671282|date=June 17, 2010|accessdate=June 19, 2010}}</ref> * The [[WACA Ground]] in Perth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waca.com.au/ground/at-the-ground/ground-entry-conditions|title=Ground Entry Conditions - WACA Western Australia Cricket Association|website=www.waca.com.au|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> * [[The Gabba]] Cricket Ground in Brisbane.<ref>http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/the-ashes-2017-barmy-armys-new-chants-revealed-before-gabba-test/news-story/217258319be9b13bc92cd43d70ef06aa</ref> * The [[Sydney Cricket Ground]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketnsw.com.au/news/attending-the-odi-between-australia-and-india-at-the-scg/2012-02-24|title=Attending the ODI between Australia and India at the SCG|publisher=|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> * The now defunct [[Champion's League Twenty20]] cricket tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2010/sep/08/county-cricket-live|title=County cricket - as it happened! - Andy Wilson, Rob Smyth and Vic Marks|first1=Vic|last1=Marks|first2=Andy|last2=Wilson|first3=Rob|last3=Smyth|date=September 8, 2010|website=the Guardian|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> * [[Yankee Stadium]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Vuvuzelas BANNED From Yankee Stadium |work=The Huffington Post|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/17/vuvuzelas-banned-from-yan_n_616282.html|date=June 17, 2010|accessdate=June 19, 2010}}</ref> * [[Fuji Rock Festival]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fujirockfestival.com/news/?id=969|title=ブブゼラの持ち込み及び使用禁止のお願い|work=FujiRockFestival.com|publisher=SMASH Corporation|date=July 15, 2010}}</ref> * The [[Southeastern Conference]] of US college sports<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ajc.com/sports/sec-leave-your-vuvuzelas-557799.html|author=Kristi E. Swartz|title=SEC: leave your vuvuzelas at home|publisher=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|accessdate=2010-07-05}}</ref> * [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] events.<ref>{{Cite news|title=No Vuvuzelas allowed at UFC card|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/extra/mma/news/story?id=5343197|publisher=ESPN|agency=Associated Press|date=June 30, 2010}}</ref> * [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] events<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0618/1224272793785.html |title=GAA bans vuvuzelas before they blow away the Croke Park atmosphere – The Irish Times – Fri, Jun 18, 2010 |work=The Irish Times |date=June 18, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-14}}</ref> * [[Little League World Series]] (from 2010 onward) * [[Jeld-Wen Field]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.pgepark.com/guest-guide |title=Guest Guide |publisher=Portland Timbers |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110127134957/http://www.pgepark.com/guest-guide |archive-date=January 27, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[UEFA]], including all [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]], [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]], and [[European Championship]] matches<ref>[http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/5518726/uefa-bans-vuvuzelas-euro-2012-champions-league UEFA Enacts Vuvuzelas Ban], ''ESPN.com'', September 1, 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.ie/archives/football/196733/euro-2016-uefa-bans-toilet-roll-painted-faces-and-vuvuzelas/|title=Euro 2016: UEFA bans toilet roll, painted faces, and vuvuzelas|date=May 31, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> * [[Rugby World Cup]] (starting in [[2011 Rugby World Cup|2011]])<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sarugby.com/news/News/article/sid=13830.html|title=No vuvuzelas at RWC 2011|work=SARugby.com|publisher=SARugby.com|date=June 29, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703061050/http://www.sarugby.com/news/News/article/sid%3D13830.html|archivedate=July 3, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Kontinental Hockey League]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khl.ru/news/2010/7/23/27717.html |script-title=ru:КХЛ налагает запрет на использование вувузел |date=July 23, 2010 |publisher=[[Kontinental Hockey League]] |accessdate=July 23, 2010 |language=Russian}}</ref> * [[2010 FIBA World Championship]] and other basketball tournaments from then on<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportas.delfi.lt/eurobasket2003/pasaulio-krepsinio-cempionate-vuvuzelu-negirdesime.d?id=35095573 |title=Pasaulio krepšinio čempionate vuvuzelų negirdėsime – DELFI Žinios |publisher=Sportas.delfi.lt |accessdate=2010-09-14}}</ref> * [[National Football League]] (as part of an overall ban of noisemakers) * [[Evolution Championship Series|The Evolution Championship Series]] for [[Fighting game|fighting]] [[Electronic sports|games]]. * [[Vermont Principals' Association]] [[Amateur sports#High school sports|High school sports]]
[[File:Sneijder Heitinga.jpg|thumb|left|[[Wesley Sneijder]] blowing on a vuvuzela]] Some shopping centres in South Africa banned the use of vuvuzelas.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ewn.co.za/articleprog.aspx?id=41683|title=No vuvuzelas inside Sandton City|work=Eyewitness News|publisher=Primedia Broadcasting|last=Child|first=Katharine|date=June 12, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006054626/http://www.ewn.co.za/articleprog.aspx?id=41683|archivedate=October 6, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=vn20100616043817493C787065|title=Shopping mall silences vuvuzela|date=June 16, 2010|work=IOL|last=Dardagan|first=Colleen|agency=South African Press Association}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/sport/soccer/article.aspx?id=410355|title=Vuvuzelas get red card in malls|publisher=Avusa Media Limited|work=Daily Dispatch Online|first=Msindisi|last=Fengu|date=June 18, 2010}}</ref> They were also banned at the 2010 [[Baltimore]] [[anime convention]] [[Otakon]],<ref name="Otakon">{{Cite news|url=http://www.otakon.com/news_article.asp?id=539|title=Vuvuzela ban in effect|first=Arruda|last=Lou|date=July 11, 2010|work=Otakon.com}}</ref> the convention committee declared that any attendee carrying a vuvuzela could have it confiscated from them, and that anyone blowing one could face expulsion from the event.<ref name="Otakon" /><ref name="ANNOta">{{Cite news|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2010-07-14/no-vuvuzelas-at-otakon|title=No Vuvuzelas at Otakon|date=July 14, 2010|work=Anime News Network}}</ref>
Another such action was taken in response to the prevalence of the vuvuzelas at the 2010 [[Anime Expo]] based in Los Angeles, attended by representatives of Otakon who felt the disruption led to discomfort for some of the attendees of Anime Expo which they wished to avoid at the later Baltimore event.<ref name="ANNOta" />
Nine English [[Premier League]] clubs have banned the device. Five clubs ([[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/vuvuzelas-not-welcome- |title=Vuvuzelas not welcome at Emirates Stadium! |publisher=Arsenal.com |date=July 20, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-14}}</ref> [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) have banned them due to health and safety reasons while [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], and [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] have barred them because of policy against musical instruments. [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] banned vuvuzelas from [[Old Trafford]] on August 13, 2010. However, two clubs ([[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]]) have allowed them. {{citation needed|date=September 2010}}
The organisers of the [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 Olympic Games]] placed a ban on vuvuzelas at the sporting event.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/news/no-frisbees-picnic-hampers-or-vuvuzelas-items-banned-from-the-london-2012-olympics-7936428.html |title= No frisbees, picnic hampers or vuvuzelas: items banned from the London 2012 Olympics |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= July 12, 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate= August 30, 2012}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Usage in protests== On July 13, 2010, protesters with vuvuzelas converged on [[BP]]'s London headquarters to protest the company's handling of the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]].<ref>{{Cite news | author = CNN Wire Staff | title = Vuvuzela protest planned at BP HQ | work = CNN.com Breaking News | publisher = CNN | date = July 13, 2010 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/07/13/uk.bp.vuvuzela.protest/ }}</ref>
In [[Wisconsin]], the Anti-[[Scott Walker (politician)|Walker]], pro-[[Labor unions in the United States|union]] [[2011 Wisconsin protests|protesters]] have made extensive use of vuvuzelas. A Madison DJ, Nick Nice, [http://www.thedailypage.com/isthmus/article.php?article=33472 ordered 200] and distributed them to his fellow protesters. The Madison police even issued permits for use of the vuvuzelas ''inside'' the capitol.{{Citation needed|date=June 2012}}
In March 2012, German protesters used vuvuzelas during the official traditional torchlight ceremony, the [[Großer Zapfenstreich]], which bid farewell to [[President of Germany]] [[Christian Wulff]]. Wulff had resigned earlier over corruption allegations, yet he still received the honor of the military ceremony, which left Germany divided. [http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,820452,00.html]
== Usage in music == Usage of vuvuzela in art music is limited. One of the few compositions made for it is a baroque-style [[double concerto]] in C major for vuvuzela, [[organ (music)|organ]] (or [[harpsichord]]) and string orchestra, written by [[Timo Kiiskinen]], Professor of Church Music in [[Sibelius Academy]], [[Helsinki]]; organ version of this concerto was premiered on 21st October 2010 at the Organ Hall of Sibelius Academy, and harpsichord version on 19th December 2010 at Pro Puu gallery in Lahti.<ref>https://cris.uniarts.fi/crisyp/disp/_/fi/cr_redir_all/fet/fet/sea?direction=2&id=3477372 (in Finnish)</ref><ref>"Barokkiyhtyeen joulukonsertissa soi vuvuzela" [http://www.ess.fi/uutiset/kulttuurijaviihde/2010/12/16/barokkiyhtyeen-joulukonsertissa-soi-vuvuzela]. ''Etelä-Suomen sanomat'' 16.12.2010 (in Finnish)</ref>
Alternative rock band Catzo Music All-Stars used two vuvuzelas as the basis of its 2010 song "Larissa Riquelme (reprise)".
==See also== * [[Makarapa]] — hand-made hats worn by spectators to show their team support * [[Air horn#Portable or personal air horns|Portable or personal air horns]] — produce sounds similar to the vuvuzela * [[Ratchet (instrument)|Football rattle]] — a percussion instrument which produces a clicking and rattling noise * [[Thundersticks]] — narrow plastic balloons used as promotional noise makers
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Vuvuzelas}} {{Wiktionary}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/africa/10312794.stm 10 Things about the Vuvuzela by the BBC] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7X3fkvhd-5g Promotional film for World Cup Mexico 86 – Mexican plastic trumpets are shown] – YouTube * [http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/64381,in-pictures,news-in-pictures,vuvuzela-day-in-pictures-bafana-world-cup-football-south-africa Vuvuzela Day] – slideshow by ''[[The First Post]]'' * {{cite web|last=Moriarty|first=Philip|title=Vuvuzela|url=http://www.sixtysymbols.com/videos/vuvuzela.htm|work=Sixty Symbols|publisher=[[Brady Haran]] for the [[University of Nottingham]]|year=2010}}

{{More citations needed|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film festival | name = Washington Jewish Film Festival | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_size = | image = | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | telephone = | founded = 1989 | awardsreceived = | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = [[Washington, D.C. Jewish Community Center]] | number = | date = | language = | website = {{URL|www.wjff.org}} }} The '''Washington Jewish Film Festival''' (WJFF), in [[Washington, D.C.]], is one of the world's oldest and largest Jewish film festivals. Focusing on Jewish and Israeli issues, the festival has shown hundreds of films ranging both in genre and theme and held in the Aaron & Cecile Goldman Theater in the Washington DC Jewish Community Center and other cinemas in Washington and suburban Maryland and Virginia. The festival was founded by [[Aviva Kempner]] in 1989 and has successfully run for over twenty years and is presented by the Washington DCJCC's Morris Cafritz Center for the Arts.
==Mission== '''Promote the preservation of Jewish culture and a diversity of narratives.''' The Festival provides a forum for films with Jewish themes that most often do not otherwise find a place for public exhibition in the [[Washington, D.C.]] area. Many of the films we screen only have a life on the Festival circuit and in specialty DVD-release meaning that attendees have the opportunity to experience rarely seen films.
'''Encourage Innovation and vitality within Jewish culture.''' The festival highlights films that place Jewish themes in new contexts or challenge long-held assumptions. The WJFF is at the forefront of presenting films that provide a constructive critique of Jewish identity and reconsider major cultural guideposts such as Zionism, the Holocaust and assimilation as well as the place of women, homosexuals and other people of diverse backgrounds and lifestyles in Jewish life and tradition.
'''Expose the widest possible audience to a low-cost, low barrier entry to the Jewish culture.''' Because the Jewish Diaspora has interacted with numerous host cultures over the course of its long history, the Festival seeks out films that examine some aspect of the Jewish experience, which often act as a prism through which to view multiple cultures. The festival is also dedicated to presenting films which will engage a wide audience at the lowest possible cost.
'''Provide a forum for audiences to interact with filmmakers and for filmmakers to receive feedback.''' Filmmakers attending the Festival engage in open and energetic dialogue with the Festival's audience. Through the works-in-progress program for uncompleted projects, the Festival provides new and veteran filmmakers opportunities to screen works-in-progress portions of their films for an audience at a critical point in their creative process.<ref name="mission">[https://www.wjff.org/about/]</ref>
==Staff, Council and Committee== The success of the WJFF is the result of the combined effort of the full-time staff and the Film Council. As of 2018 the WJFF is led by individuals following below:
:'''WJFF Staff''' :*Director: Ilya Tovbis :*Associate Director of Operations: Kaitlin Whitman :*Outreach and Communications Manager: Alexis Rodriguez :*Administrative Coordinator: Carolyn Hoehner
:'''WJFF Film Council''' :*Co-Chairs: Dina Gold and Sid Moskowitz :*Patty Abramson :*Michele Berman :*Anne Clemons :*Ed Cohen :*Sara Cohen :*Myrna L. Fawcett :*Stephanie Flack :*Morgan Greenhouse Genderson :*Margie Hoffman :*Joy Midman :*Eric Siegel :*Sue-Ann Siegel :*Barbara Silverstein :*Richard Solloway :*Diana Wattenberg :*WJFF Advisor and Founder: Aviva Kempner
WJFF Year-Round is the year-round exhibition arm of the Washington Jewish Film Festival, presenting entertaining and thought-provoking features, documentaries and shorts from around the world on a (approximately) weekly basis at the Aaron & Cecile Goldman Theater at the Edlavitch DCJCC. Most screenings are accompanied by speakers including filmmakers and scholars.<ref name="mission"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.wjff.org Official website]

revision.text:
[[File:Hawk eating prey.jpg|thumb|A juvenile [[red-tailed hawk]] eating a [[california vole]]]] '''Wild animal suffering''' is the [[suffering]] experienced by nonhuman animals in nature through causes such as disease, injury, starvation, natural disasters, and killings by other animals. Wild animal suffering has historically been discussed in the context of [[philosophy of religion]] as an instance of the [[problem of evil]].{{cite book|last1=Darwin|first1=Charles|authorlink1=Charles Darwin|editor1-last=Barlow|editor1-first=Nora|title=The Autobiography of Charles Darwin: 1809-1882|date=September 1993|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0393310696|page=90}}{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=C. S.|authorlink1=C. S. Lewis|title=The Problem of Pain|year=2015|publisher=HarperOne|isbn=9780060652968}}{{cite book|last1=Murray|first1=Michael|title=Nature Red in Tooth and Claw: Theism and the Problem of Animal Suffering|date=April 30, 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0199596324|url=https://www.amazon.com/Nature-Red-Tooth-Claw-Suffering/dp/0199596328/}}{{cite journal|last=Gould|first=Stephen|authorlink1=Stephen Jay Gould|title=Nonmoral Nature|journal=Natural History|date=February 1982|volume=91|issue=2|pages=19–26|url=http://www.pagefarm.net--www.pagefarm.net/ap/PDFs/nmn.pdf|accessdate=19 January 2014}}{{cite book|last1=McMahan|first1=Jeff|authorlink1=Jeff McMahan (philosopher)|editor1-last=Chignell|editor1-first=Andrew|editor2-last=Cuneo|editor2-first=Terence|editor3-last=Halteman|editor3-first=Matt|title=Philosophy Comes to Dinner: Arguments on the Ethics of Eating.|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0415806831|chapter=The Moral Problem of Predation}} More recently, a number of academics have considered the suspected scope of the problem from a secular standpoint as a general moral issue, one that humans might be able to take action towards preventing.{{cite journal|last1=Dorado|first1=Daniel|title=Ethical Interventions in the Wild. An Annotated Bibliography|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|year=2015|volume=3|issue=2|pages=219–238|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/887|accessdate=21 April 2016|doi=10.7358/rela-2015-002-dora}}{{cite journal|last1=Moen|first1=Ole Martin|title=The Ethics of Wild Animal Suffering|journal=Etikk i Praksis - Nordic Journal of Applied Ethics|year=2016|pages=1–14|url=http://www.olemartinmoen.com/wp-content/uploads/TheEthicsofWildAnimalSuffering.pdf|accessdate=8 May 2016|doi=10.5324/eip.v10i1.1972}}{{cite journal|last=|first=|date=|year=2015|title=The Problem of Evil in Nature: Evolutionary Bases of the Prevalence of Disvalue|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/825|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|volume=3|issue=1|pages=17–32|doi=10.7358/rela-2015-001-hort|pmid=|access-date=|via=|last1=Horta|first1=Oscar|accessdate=8 May 2016}}{{cite journal|last1=Torres|first1=Mikel|title=The Case for Intervention in Nature on Behalf of Animals: A Critical Review of the Main Arguments against Intervention|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|year=2015|volume=3|issue=1|pages=33–49|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/824|accessdate=8 May 2016}}{{cite journal|last1=Cunha|first1=Luciano Carlos|title=If Natural Entities Have Intrinsic Value, Should We Then Abstain from Helping Animals Who Are Victims of Natural Processes?|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|year=2015|volume=3|issue=1|pages=51–63|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/823|accessdate=8 May 2016|doi=10.7358/rela-2015-001-cunh}}{{cite journal|last1=Tomasik|first1=Brian|title=The Importance of Wild-Animal Suffering|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|year=2015|volume=3|issue=2|pages=133–152|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/880|accessdate=8 May 2016|doi=10.7358/rela-2015-002-toma}}{{cite journal|last=Pearce|first=David|authorlink1=David Pearce (philosopher)|title=A Welfare State For Elephants? A Case Study of Compassionate Stewardship|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|year=2015|volume=3|issue=2|pages=153–164|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/881|accessdate=8 May 2016|doi=10.7358/rela-2015-002-pear}}{{cite journal|last=Paez|first=Eze|title=Refusing Help and Inflicting Harm. A Critique of the Environmentalist View|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|year=2015|volume=3|issue=2|pages=165–178|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/882|accessdate=8 May 2016|doi=10.7358/rela-2015-002-paez}}{{cite journal|last=Sözmen|first=Beril|title=Relations and Moral Obligations towards Other Animals|journal=Relations. Beyond Anthropocentrism|year=2015|volume=3|issue=2|pages=179–193|url=http://www.ledonline.it/index.php/Relations/article/view/883|accessdate=8 May 2016|doi=10.7358/rela-2015-002-sozm}}{{cite thesis |type=Ph.D. |last=Faria |first=Catia |date=2016 |title=Animal Ethics Goes Wild: The Problem of Wild Animal Suffering and Intervention in Nature|publisher=Universitat Pompeu Fabra}} There is considerable disagreement around this latter point, as many believe that human intervention in nature would be either unethical, unfeasible, or both. == Extent of suffering in nature == In his [[The Autobiography of Charles Darwin|autobiography]], [[Charles Darwin]] acknowledged that the existence of extensive suffering in nature was fully compatible with the workings of natural selection, yet maintained that [[Reinforcement#Reinforcement|pleasure]] was the main driver of fitness-increasing behavior in organisms. Evolutionary biologist [[Richard Dawkins]] challenged Darwin's claim in his book ''[[River Out of Eden]]'', wherein he argued that wild animal suffering must be extensive due to the interplay of the following evolutionary mechanisms: * [[Gene-centered view of evolution|Selfish genes]] – genes are wholly indifferent to the well-being of individual organisms as long as DNA is passed on. * [[Struggle for existence|The struggle for existence]] – competition over limited resources results in the majority of organisms dying before passing on their genes. * [[Malthusian catastrophe|Malthusian checks]] – even bountiful periods within a given ecosystem eventually lead to overpopulation and subsequent population crashes. From this, Dawkins concludes that the natural world must necessarily contain enormous amounts of animal suffering as an inevitable consequence of [[Natural selection|Darwinian evolution]].{{cite book|last1=Dawkins|first1=Richard|title=River Out of Eden|date=1995|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=0-465-01606-5|chapter=Chapter 4: God's Utility Function}} To illustrate this he wrote:[[File:Mouse litter.jpg|thumb|A litter of [[House mouse|mice]] with their mother. The reproduction of mice follows an ''r''-selection strategy, with many offspring, short gestation, less parental care, and a short time until sexual maturity.]]
The total amount of suffering per year in the natural world is beyond all decent contemplation. During the minute that it takes me to compose this sentence, thousands of animals are being eaten alive, many others are running for their lives, whimpering with fear, others are slowly being devoured from within by rasping parasites, thousands of all kinds are dying of starvation, thirst, and disease. It must be so. If there ever is a time of plenty, this very fact will automatically lead to an increase in the population until the natural state of starvation and misery is restored.{{Cite book|title=River Out of Eden: A Darwinian View of Life|last=Dawkins|first=Richard|publisher=|year=1995|isbn=9781857994056|location=|pages=}}
Building on this, others have argued that the prevalence of [[r-selection|r-selected animals]] in the wild indicates that the average life of a wild animal is likely to be very short and end in a painful death. According to this view, the average life of a wild animal should thus contain more suffering than happiness, since a painful death would outweigh any short-lived moments of happiness in their short lives.{{cite journal|last=Horta|first=Oscar|title=Debunking the Idyllic View of Natural Processes: Population Dynamics and Suffering in the Wild|journal=Télos|year=2010|volume=17|issue=1|pages=73–88|url=https://www.academia.edu/2290959/Debunking_the_Idyllic_View_of_Natural_Processes_Population_Dynamics_and_Suffering_in_the_Wild}}{{cite journal|last=Ng|first=Yew-Kwang|authorlink1=Yew-Kwang Ng|title=Towards Welfare Biology: Evolutionary Economics of Animal Consciousness and Suffering|journal=Biology and Philosophy|year=1995|volume=10|issue=3|pages=255–285|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF00852469|doi=10.1007/BF00852469}} In ''Bambi or Bessie: Are Wild Animals Happier?'' Christie Wilcox argues that wild animals do not appear to be happier than domestic animals, based on findings of wild animals having greater levels of cortisol and elevated stress responses relative to domestic animals. Additionally, unlike domestic animals, animals in the wild do not have some of their needs provided for them by human caretakers.{{cite web|last=Wilcox|first=Christie|title=Bambi or Bessie: Are Wild Animals Happier?|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/2011/04/12/bambi-or-bessie-are-wild-animals-happier/|publisher=Scientific American|accessdate=8 May 2016|date=12 April 2011}} Welfare economist [[Yew-Kwang Ng]] has written that evolutionary dynamics can lead to animal welfare which is worse than necessary for a given population equilibrium. ==Philosophical status== === History of concern for wild animals === In the essay 'On Nature', [[utilitarian]] philosopher [[John Stuart Mill]] wrote about suffering in nature and the normativity of struggling against it:
In sober truth, nearly all the things which men are hanged or imprisoned for doing to one another, are nature's every day performances. [...] The phrases which ascribe perfection to the course of nature can only be considered as the exaggerations of poetic or devotional feeling, not intended to stand the test of a sober examination. No one, either religious or irreligious, believes that the hurtful agencies of nature, considered as a whole, promote good purposes, in any other way than by inciting human rational creatures to rise up and struggle against them. [...] Whatsoever, in nature, gives indication of beneficent design proves this beneficence to be armed only with limited power; and the duty of man is to cooperate with the beneficent powers, not by imitating, but by perpetually striving to amend, the course of nature - and bringing that part of it over which we can exercise control more nearly into conformity with a high standard of justice and goodness.{{cite news|title=On Nature |url=https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/mill-john-stuart/1874/nature.htm |accessdate=10 July 2016}}
The English writer and naturalist [[Henry Stephens Salt]] wrote an entire chapter on the plight of wild animals, 'The Case of Wild Animals', in his 1894 book [[Animals' Rights: Considered in Relation to Social Progress]]. Salt wrote that:
It is of the utmost importance to emphasize the fact that, whatever the legal fiction may have been, or may still be, the rights of animals are not morally dependent on the so-called rights of property; it is not to owned animals merely that we must extend our sympathy and protection. [...] To take advantage of the sufferings of animals, whether wild or tame, for the gratification of sport, or gluttony, or fashion, is quite incompatible with any possible assertion of animals' rights.{{cite news|title=Animals' Rights: Considered in Relation to Social Progress |url=http://www.animal-rights-library.com/texts-c/salt01.htm |accessdate=5 July 2016}}
Salt argued that humans are justified in killing wild animals in self-defense, but that "[...] we are not justified in unnecessarily killing—still less in torturing—any harmless beings whatsoever." He argues that this applies to insects as well: "We are unable to give life, and therefore ought not to take it away from the meanest insect without sufficient reason.'" In 1991, the environmental philosopher [[Arne Naess (philosopher)|Arne Naess]] critiqued what he termed the "cult of nature" of contemporary and historical attitudes of indifference towards suffering in nature. He argued that we should confront the reality of the wilderness and that we should be prepared to disturb natural processes when feasible to relieve suffering.{{cite journal|last1=Naess|first1=Arne|title=Should We Try to Relieve Clear Cases of Suffering in Nature?|journal=Pan Ecology|date=1991|volume=6|pages=1–5|url=https://www.abolitionist.com/reprogramming/suffering-nature.pdf|accessdate=20 November 2016}} === Ecology as intrinsically valuable === [[Holmes Rolston III]] argues that only unnatural animal suffering is a morally bad thing and that humans do not have a duty to intervene in natural cases.{{cite book|last1=Rolston III|first1=Holmes|title=Environmental Ethics: Duties To and Values in the Natural World|date=1988|publisher=Temple University Press|isbn=9780877225010|url=https://www.amazon.com/Environmental-Ethics-Duties-Values-Natural/dp/0877226288|accessdate=10 June 2014}} He celebrates carnivores in nature because of the significant ecological role they play. Others have argued that the reason that humans have a duty to protect other humans from predation is because humans are part of the cultural world rather than the natural world and so different rules apply to them in these situations.{{cite journal|last=Hettinger|first=Ned|title=Valuing Predation in Rolston's Environmental Ethics|journal=Environmental Ethics|year=1994|volume=16|issue=1|pages=3–20|doi=10.5840/enviroethics199416138}}{{cite journal|last=Moriarty|first=Paul|author2=Mark Woods |title=Hunting ≠ Predation|journal=Environmental Ethics|year=1997|volume=19|issue=4|pages=391–404|doi=10.5840/enviroethics19971945}} Others argue that prey animals are fulfilling their natural function, and thus flourishing, when they are preyed upon or otherwise die, since this allows natural selection to work. === Wild animal suffering as a ''reductio ad absurdum'' === That people would also be obliged to intervene in nature has been used as a ''[[reductio ad absurdum]]'' against the position that animals have rights. This is because, if animals such as prey animals did have rights, people would be obliged to intervene in nature to protect them, but this is claimed to be absurd.{{cite journal|last=Benatar|first=David|authorlink1=David Benatar|title=Why the Naïve Argument against Moral Vegetarianism Really is Naïve|journal=Environmental Values|date=February 2001|volume=10|issue=1|pages=103–112|doi=10.3197/096327101129340769|jstor=30301788}}{{cite journal|last=Ebert|first=Rainer|title=Innocent Threats and the Moral Problem of Carnivorous Animals|journal=Journal of Applied Philosophy|year=2012|volume=29|issue=2|pages=146–159|doi=10.1111/j.1468-5930.2012.00561.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-5930.2012.00561.x/abstract}} An objection to this argument is that people do not see intervening in the natural world to save other people from predation as absurd and so this could be seen to involve treating non-human animals differently in this situation without justification.{{cite journal|last=Horta|first=Oscar|title= Disvalue in nature and intervention|journal=Pensata Animal|year=2010|volume=34|url=https://www.academia.edu/download/7822811/DisvalueNatureIntervention.pdf}} === Relevance to the theological problem of evil === {{Main|Problem of evil#Problem of evil and animal suffering}} The [[problem of evil]] has been extended beyond human troubles to include the suffering of animals over the course of evolution.{{cite book|author=Nicola Hoggard Creegan|title=Animal Suffering and the Problem of Evil|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xB1pAgAAQBAJ |year=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-993185-9 |pages=44–55}} == Interventions to reduce suffering == === Arguments for intervention === Some theorists have reflected on whether we should accept the harms that animals suffer in nature or try to do something to mitigate them. The moral basis for interventions aimed at reducing wild animal suffering can be rights-based or welfare-based. From a rights-based perspective, if animals have a moral right to life or bodily integrity, intervention may be required to prevent such rights from being violated by other animals.{{cite journal|last=Aaltola|first=Elisa|authorlink1=Elisa Aaltola|title=Animal Ethics and the Argument from Absurdity|journal=Environmental Values|date=February 2010|volume=19|issue=1|pages=79–98|doi=10.3197/096327110X485392|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/whp/ev/2010/00000019/00000001/art00006|accessdate=10 January 2014}} From a welfare-based perspective, a requirement to intervene may arise insofar as it is possible to prevent some of the suffering experienced by wild animals without causing even more suffering. Advocates of intervention in nature argue that nonintervention is inconsistent with either of these approaches. Some proposed courses of action include removing predators from wild areas,{{cite web|last1=MacAskill|first1=William|last2=MacAskill|first2=Amanda|title=To Truly End Animal Suffering, the Most Ethical Choice is To Kill Wild Predators (Especially Cecil the Lion)|url=http://qz.com/497675/to-truly-end-animal-suffering-the-most-ethical-choice-is-to-kill-all-predators-especially-cecil-the-lion/|publisher=Quartz|accessdate=17 April 2016|date=9 September 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Grush|first1=Loren|title=Killing off wild predators is a stupid idea|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/9/10/9308195/killing-off-wild-predators-is-a-stupid-idea|website=The Verge|date=10 September 2015}} refraining from reintroducing predators,{{cite journal|last=Horta|first=Oscar|title=The Ethics of the Ecology of Fear against the Nonspeciesist Paradigm A Shift in the Aims of Intervention in Nature|journal=[[Between the Species]]|year=2010|volume=13|issue=10|pages=163–187|url=http://digitalcommons.calpoly.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1114&context=bts|doi=10.15368/bts.2010v13n10.10}} providing medical care to sick or injured animals,{{cite web|last1=Reese|first1=Jacy|title=Wild animals endure illness, injury, and starvation. We should help.|url=https://www.vox.com/2015/12/14/9873012/wild-animals-suffering|publisher=Vox|accessdate=17 April 2016|date=14 December 2015}} and rescuing wild animals from natural disasters. === The practicality of intervening in nature === A common objection to intervening in nature is that it would be impractical, either because of the amount of work involved, or because the complexity of ecosystems would make it difficult to know whether or not an intervention would be net beneficial on balance.{{cite news|last=McMahan|first=Jeff|title=Predators: A Response|url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/28/predators-a-response/?_r=0|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=27 December 2013|date=September 28, 2010}} Aaron Simmons argues that we should not intervene to save animals in nature because doing so would result in [[unintended consequences]] such as damaging the ecosystem, interfering with human projects, or resulting more animal deaths overall.{{cite journal|last=Simmons|first=Aaron|title=Animals, Predators, The Right to Life and The Duty to Save Lives|journal=Ethics & The Environment|year=2009|volume=14|issue=1|doi=10.2979/ete.2009.14.1.15| pages=15–27|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/een/summary/v014/14.1.simmons.html}} Philosopher [[Peter Singer]] has argued that intervention in nature would be justified if one could be reasonably confident that this would greatly reduce wild animal suffering and death in the long run. In practice, however, Singer cautions against interfering with ecosystems because he fears that doing so would cause more harm than good.{{cite journal|last1=Singer|first1=Peter|title=Food for Thought|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1973/jun/14/food-for-thought/|journal=[[The New York Review of Books]]|accessdate=23 February 2015|date=June 14, 1973}}{{cite book|last1=Singer|first1=Peter|title=The Point of View of The Universe|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0199603695|page=346}} Other authors dispute Singer's empirical claim about the likely consequences of intervening in the natural world, and argue that some types of intervention can be expected to produce good consequences overall. Economist [[Tyler Cowen]] cites examples of animal species whose extinction is not generally regarded as having been on balance bad for the world. Cowen also notes that, insofar as humans are already intervening in nature, the relevant practical question is not whether we should intervene at all, but what particular forms of intervention we should favor.{{cite journal|last=Cowen|first=Tyler|title=Policing Nature|journal=Environment Ethics|year=2003|volume=25|issue=2|pages=169–182|doi=10.5840/enviroethics200325231}} Philosopher Oscar Horta similarly writes that there are already many cases in which we intervene in nature for other reasons, such as for human interest in nature and environmental preservation as something valuable in their own rights.{{cite journal|last=Horta|first=Oscar|title=Debunking the Idyllic View of Natural Processes: Population Dynamics and Suffering in the Wild|journal=Télos|year=2010|volume=17|issue=1|pages=73–88|url=https://www.academia.edu/2290959/Debunking_the_Idyllic_View_of_Natural_Processes_Population_Dynamics_and_Suffering_in_the_Wild}} Likewise, moral philosopher [[Jeff McMahan (philosopher)|Jeff McMahan]] argues that, since humans "are already causing massive, precipitate changes in the natural world," we should favor those changes that would promote the survival "of herbivorous rather than carnivorous species." [[Peter Vallentyne]] suggests that, while humans should not eliminate predators in nature, they can intervene to help prey in more limited ways. In the same way that we help humans in need when the cost to us is small, we might help some wild animals at least in limited circumstances.{{cite news|last1=Verchot|first1=Manon|title=Meet the people who want to turn predators into vegans|url=http://www.treehugger.com/natural-sciences/meet-the-people-who-want-to-turn-predators-into-vegans.html|accessdate=2 October 2014|agency=TreeHugger|date=30 Sep 2014}} === Potential conflict between animal rights and environmentalism === It has been argued that the common environmentalist goal of preserving the natural order is not in line with the goal of looking after the welfare of sentient animals.{{cite book|last=Belshaw|first=Christoher|title=Environmental Philosophy|year=2001|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=1-902683-21-8|page=xii}} It has been further argued that they conflict in different cases. Examples include environmentalists supporting hunting invasive species for population control while animal rights advocates oppose it;{{cite journal|last1=Horta|first1=Oscar|title=What Is Speciesism?|journal=Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics|year=2010|volume=23|issue=3|pages=243–266|url=http://masalladelaespecie.files.wordpress.com/2010/05/whatisspeciesism.pdf|doi=10.1007/s10806-009-9205-2|accessdate=10 June 2014}} animal rights advocates arguing for the extinction or reengineering of carnivores or ''r'' strategist species while deep ecologists defend their right to be and flourish as they are;{{cite web|last=Pearce|first=David|title=Reprogramming Predators|year=2009|url=http://www.hedweb.com/abolitionist-project/reprogramming-predators.html|publisher=HEDWEB|accessdate=8 May 2016}} animal rights advocates defending the reduction of wildlife areas or arguing against their expansion out of concern that most animal suffering takes place in them while environmentalists want to safeguard and expand the wild.{{cite journal|last=Sagoff|first=Mark|title=Animal Liberation and Environmental Ethics: Bad Marriage, Quick Divorce|journal=Osgoode Hall Law Journal|year=1984|volume=22|issue=2|pages=297–307|url=http://digitalcommons.osgoode.yorku.ca/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1936&context=ohlj}} === History of interventions === In 2016, 350 starving [[hippo]]s and [[African buffalo|buffalo]]es at [[Kruger National Park]] were killed by park rangers. One of the motives for the action was to prevent the animals from suffering as they died.{{cite web|last1=Burke|first1=Jason|title=South African national park to kill animals in response to severe drought|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/14/south-african-national-park-kill-animals-severe-drought|website=The Guardian|accessdate=20 November 2016|date=14 September 2016}} == See also == {{Div col}} * [[Animal Rights]] * [[Appeal to nature]] * [[Environmental philosophy]] * [[God's utility function]] * [[The Problem of Evil]] * [[The Problem of Pain]] * [[Speciesism]] * [[Suffering]] * [[Utilitarianism]] * [[Emotion in animals]] * [[Pain in animals]] * [[Pain in invertebrates]] * [[Pain in amphibians]] * [[Pain in cephalopods]] * [[Pain in crustaceans]] * [[Pain in fish]] {{div col end}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://was-research.org Wild-Animal Suffering Research] * {{Wikiquote-inline|Wild animal suffering}} *[http://www.animal-ethics.org/wild-animal-suffering-section/ Wild Animal Suffering - Animal Ethics] *[https://www.academia.edu/17961205/Ethical_Interventions_in_the_Wild_An_Annotated_Bibliography Ethical Interventions in the Wild: An Annotated Bibliography] *[http://www.stafforini.com/blog/wild-animal-suffering-a-bibliography/ Wild Animal Suffering: A Bibliography] {{Animal welfare}} {{Animal rights}} {{Ethics}} [[Category:Animal rights]] [[Category:Animal welfare]] [[Category:Cruelty to animals]] [[Category:Environmental ethics]] [[Category:Issues in ethics]]
